title: Meghan Markle father Thomas race Prince Harry Royal Family
story: Before her relationship with Prince Harry was announced she revealed how her father responded when as a child she returned from school unhappy.&nbspMs Markle explained how before an English exam she had to fill out a form, which included ticking a box for her race.&nbspThe four options were &lsquowhite&rsquo, &lsquoblack&rsquo, &lsquoHiic&rsquo and &lsquoAsian&rsquo.&nbspThis presented a problem for the young Ms Markle, the mixed race daughter of a black mother and white father.&nbsp                Meghan Markle&rsquos father Thomas Markle makes these claims about royals                Meghan Markle&rsquos father compares Royal Family to a CULTShe said she didn&rsquot know which box to tick, so left it blank.&nbspLater she discussed it with her father, who became angry at what he perceived as the racial insensitive question.&nbspMs Markle explained: &ldquoIt made the green of his eyes pop and his brow was weighted at the thought of his daughter pray to ignorance.&nbsp&ldquoAnd in one of those parenting moments that no guidebook could ever prep you for, my dad said words which will stay with me forever.&nbsp&ldquoDraw your own box.&nbspMy dad said words which will stay with me forever (Image: GOOD MORNING BRITAIN)&ldquoIt made the green of his eyes pop and his brow was weighted (Image:  )She added: &ldquoHe wanted me to see beyond that census placed in front of me. He wanted me to find my own truth.Ms Markle has spoken previously about struggling with her identity as a mixed race child in her early years.&nbspIn another endearing story involving her father she revealed that for her Christmas present he once purchased two barbie boll sets, one representing a white family and the other a black family, and mixed them together to create a custom family for Meghan.&nbspShe explained: &ldquoWhen I was about seven, I have been fawning over a boxed set of Barbie dolls.&nbsp&ldquoIt was called The Heart Family and included a mum doll, a dad doll, and two children. This perfect nuclear family was only sold in sets of white dolls or black dolls.&nbsp&ldquoOn Christmas morning, swathed in glitter-flecked wrapping paper, there I found my Heart Family: a black mum doll, a white dad doll, and a child of each colour.&nbsp&ldquoMy dad had taken the sets apart and customised my family.&nbsp&ldquoOne that showed me that I should (and could) make my own box.&nbsp&ldquoOn Christmas morning, swathed in glitter-flecked wrapping paper, there I found my Heart Family (Image: )Relations between Ms Markle and her father have deteriorated recently however, with Mr Markle making a number of comments which are likely to embarrass his daughter and the Royal Family.&nbspIn a recent interview with The Sun Mr Markle described the Royal Family as &ldquocult-like - like Scientology.&nbspHe has previously claimed that Princess Diana would have &ldquoloathed the way he is treated.&nbsp

title: parking driveway southport sefton council health and safety
story: And in order to carry on parking in front of her house, Helen Maloney is looking at forking out a whopping &pound1,000.Mrs Maloney, who lives in Southport, was sent a letter from Sefton Council, warning her that her property was off limits to cars.She explained: &ldquoThe letter said I can't park on my own driveway because I don't have a dropped kerb.Apparently, by driving over the pavement in front of my house to get on to my drive, I am breaking the Highways Act.The letter from Sefton Council (Image: Liverpool Echo)She added: My next-door neighbour has a dipped kerb so she didn't get one, but others in my street did.The letter, which was also sent to other residents, states: &ldquoIt has been brought to my attention that a motorised vehicle is gaining access to your property by crossing the footway.&ldquoAs no suitable vehicular crossing has been constructed this practice is a contravention of section 184 of the Highways Act 1980.&ldquoI would strongly advise that the Highway Authority construct a crossing if you are to continue this practice.                Outrage over row of cars DOUBLE PARKED and blocking others in                Council wants to rent out YOUR driveway for &pound5-a-week to make room on Pavement parking is viewed as selfish and dangerous be many and there are petitions to have motorists caught committing this offences fined. Here are some examples of the worst offences. 1 of 25The letter gave Mrs Maloney and other recipients 14 days to contact the council&rsquos Highways Department.If she fails to comply, the council says it will carry out the work themselves &ndash and recover the cost from homeowners by taking them to court.A spokesman for Sefton Council said: The continuous driving over pavements can lead to the damage of a footway creating uneven surfaces which can also lead to trip hazards.In this instance the footway outside the property has not been dropped and we have written to the home owner informing them of this while asking them to take the necessary corrective action.This resident has since been in touch with us with the view of resolving the matter and we await further contact with her.The council's website explains that planning permission is not usually required for a dropped kerb.However, it adds that it might be necessary if the property is a listed building, is a flat, maisonette or commercial premises, or has frontage directly on a classified road.The council letter does not say how much installation of a dropped kerb will set Mrs Maloney back.But it tells people to contact the Highways Agency, which can offer advice about procedure and costs.Online quotation websites suggest the job would come in at about &pound1,000.

title: Brexit news UK EU no deal planning five industries latest
story: This week, the details of 80 planning notices set to be released by the UK Government&rsquos no-deal preparations team emerged.With talks hanging finely in the balance, the Department for Exiting the European Union is hoping to inform British business of the potential impact of a no-deal.The European Commission&rsquos no-deal preparation task force, led by powerful eurocrat Martin Selmayr, has already released 70 Brexit preparedness notices for EU member states.In a separate 15-page document issued to the EU27, warnings paint a grim picture of the consequences for the customs, animal, health, pharmaceuticals and financial services sectors as a result of a no-deal orce.According to research, more than three-quarters of the impact of Brexit will fall on just five sectors in the EU and UK.But what industries could be most hurt by Brexit if both Britain and the EU fail to conclude a deal before March 29 2019?                No-deal Brexit moves closer as UK struggles to agree with EU                Brexit news: UK pharmaceutical chief warns EU to prepare for a no-dealAutomotiveGermany&rsquos economic motor could be dealt a devastating blow if Brussels and Westminster fail to reach an agreement that allows Europe&rsquos automotive industry to continue as is it.Four of Germany&rsquos 16 states would be forced to shoulder the burden of more than three-quarters of the impact felt by a no-deal Brexit because of the automotive sectors in those regions &ndash Bavaria, North Rhine-Westphalia, Baden-Wurttemberg and Lower Saxony.According to the German association of the automotive industry, the country last year exported 769,000 cars to the UK, its single largest export destination.A study by accounting firm Deloitte showed tariffs and devaluation of the pound after a no-deal Brexit would cause thousands of job losses at German automotive suppliers.Around 42,000 jobs in Germany rely on suppliers&rsquo ties with Britain and without access it significantly risks their &euro16.9 billion in 2016 sales from UK car production.Brexit news: Five industries will shoulder three-quarters of no-deal Brexit burden (Image: )TourismBritons are prolific holidayers on the Continent, but a lack of future access &ndash the Commission has to decide whether British travellers will require visas to enter the EU &ndash major concerns are being raised.The Irish government has been told to start creating safeguard for the country&rsquos &euro5bn tourism industry and the 300,000 jobs that rely on it.Tourism Ireland chief executive Niall Gibbons warned that the diminished value of sterling is driving up the costs for short breaks.He said: &ldquoThe British take about 70m trips abroad every year, they&rsquoll continue to go to sun destinations like Spain and Turkey. But short-break destinations like Ireland are most vulnerable, so it is important that we continue to invest in Great Britain.&ldquoThey are very much our biggest volume market.However, Spain is also concerned about the possible impact on one of its largest industries.Fears that Brexit will affect tourism are voiced by Spanish regions such the Balearic Islands, including Mallorca, a popular destination for British package holidays.                Brexit negotiators &lsquohave understanding with 15 non-EU nations&rsquo                Hunt claims no deal Brexit will spark 'REGRET for generations'AgricultureAn often forgotten industry, however, farming will likely feel the pinch more than most going forward.Britain imports a great deal of meat, cheese and salad from Europe, which sparked fears of a meal deal sandwich shortage, which Britons purchase around 4 billion a year from supermarkets.On a larger scale, the Canary Islands ship more food products to the UK and any other nation. Regional officials have warned a sudden withdrawal without a free trade agreement of goods and services could ruin their businesses.Irish hauliers have also warned new shipping routes and extra checks will result in agri-food deliveries perishing because of the longer transport times.Italy's farmers are also concerned that any restriction in free trade between the Italy and the UK would devastate their industry.Roberto Moncalvo, president of Italian farming union Coldiretti said the UK&rsquos exit from the EU in March 2019 would &ldquoweaken Italy&rsquos farming industry and export trade.He warned Italian agriculture &ldquocan&rsquot pay the price of Brexit.They fear an estimated cut of &euro2.7billion (&pound2.3billion) to the budget of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), something which could heavily impact 800,000 Italian farms.                DOZENS of policy areas to feature in &lsquoNO DEAL&rsquo Brexit papers                EU deal rebuff &lsquoleaked by British spies&rsquoFinancial servicesAccording to research by management consultancy Oliver Wyman and law firm Clifford Chance, UK financial services will take by far the biggest hit given London's role as Europe's financial capital.The sector will incur about a third of the extra red tape costs, according to their study.Theresa May's White Paper outlines a willingness to take a hit to EU market access in order to be able to erge from EU relegation.However, it will also hit around 7,000 European domiciled funds ability to operate in the UK.Brussels is resisting to offer a bespoke deal on financial services, claiming the same system that works for US financial service providers will have to work for the UK.UK negotiators warned without fresh thinking, both sides would raise damaging barriers to trade.A British document reads: There is no third country equivalence regime to support the rights of around 7,000 European Economic Area domiciled funds to market to UK retail customers, who operate under the passport today.UK-based AstraZeneca has warned governments to prepare medicines for no-deal Brexit (Image: )PharmaceuticalPatients across Europe could be put at risk if Brussels and Westminster fail to strike a deal that allows the movement and regulation of drugs between the UK and the Continent.The EU should start stockpiling drugs and very quickly agree to sharing its drug safety and infectious disease databases unless it wants to put patients at risk, according to the head of the UK pharmaceutical industry.Mike Thompson, chief executive of the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry, warned the EU27 are far behind the UK in their preparation for a no-deal Brexit.Mr Thompson confirmed the Westminster has been working with drugs firms to stockpile medicines.He, however, admitted he is concerned about patients across the continent of Europe, as member states fall behind on their preparations.Cambridge-based drugs manufacturer AstraZenaeca have warned governments to follow their meticulous planning or risk medicines not being available after Brexit.AstraZeneca has spent &pound40m on its preparations, which includes building a parallel facility in Sweden incase Britain cannot agree joint regulation and standards with Brussels.

title: Brexit news UK latest today no deal vote referendum chequers European Union
story: The co-chairman of the pro-Brexit Leave Means Leave campaign group said there is an &ldquoadvantage to the short time frame that Britain has to negotiate a deal with the European Union in time for Brexit.He told BBC Radio 4&rsquos Today programme: &ldquoIt concentrates the mind. It focuses attention.Mr Tice then took a savage swipe at the civil service. He said: &ldquoAnd, frankly, if the civil servants are saying that there&rsquos not enough time, it&rsquos all too difficult, they can&rsquot do it, then actually they should step aside and let us private sector competent business Brexiteers come in and do the job because we know we can.Mr Tice also ridiculed comments made by the former head of the Home Civil Service Lord Kerslake, who said earlier in the show that Britain may have to &ldquopause it&rsquos exit from the EU and &ldquore-examine its decision to leave the bloc if the Government is unable to strike a deal with Brussels.                Brexit COMEBACK: Nigel Farage promises to KILL May's Chequers plan                Remainer Peer claims it is NECESSARY to rethink and DELAY Brexit Lord Kerslake claimed it is &ldquonecessary to delay Brexit and insisted it is &ldquonot too late to &ldquoreopen the question on whether the UK should proceed with Brexit.Mr Tice hit back at he&nbspRemainer&nbspPeer&rsquos Brexit intervention and said it was an effort to soften people up for a delay to Britain's withdrawal.He said: &ldquoThat would be absolutely appalling.&ldquoPeople up and down the country would be furious that our civil servants and Government have deliberately ignored the will of the people.&ldquoWhat we have just heard from Lord Kerslake is part of the deliberate negativity from the Civil Service who are looking to soften people up in order to extend Article 50.&ldquoIt is completely unacceptable.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt suggested on Thursday that failure to strike a Brexit deal could fuel regret for generations of Britons.Speaking at the end of a three-day tour to EU capitals to promote the Prime Minister's Chequers deal, Mr Hunt claimed a messy, ugly orce would ultimately change the relationship British citizens have with other EU member states.Brexit news: Richard Tice said it would be  (Image: &bullSky News)Sitting down with ITV's Robert Peston on Thursday, the Tory frontbencher said: It is very important we are prepared for all outcomes.&ldquoThat was something I discussed this morning with Steff Blok, the Dutch Foreign minister. We have to be prepared for that, we don&rsquot want that to happen.It would be a mistake that we would regret for generations if we have a messy, ugly orce. Inevitably that will change British attitudes to Europe.

title: Brexit news latest second referendum vote UK EU Theresa May Chequers
story: The furious Tory Brexiteer, who represents Cleethorpes, which is one of the most eurosceptic constituencies in the UK, said his constituents knew exactly what they were voting for.&nbspSpeaking exclusively to Express towards the end of July, Mr Vickers said: &ldquoThat&rsquos just an insult to the British people as a whole.&ldquoMy constituents certainly knew what they were voting for. They were voting very clearly to bring back control of our affairs and there should be no debate about it.The Tory Brexiteer also ridiculed calls for a second Brexit referendum and insisted the result of a second vote in Cleethorpes would be &ldquo70 percent plus.                &lsquoChequers plan is a CON&rsquo Leave Means Leave plots relaunch to &lsquofight th                WE control our ports, not EU! MP lashes out at Brexit scaremongeringHe added: &ldquoMany people who were marginal would say to you quite clearly that this was the will of the people and it should be implemented.Mr Vickers said his constituents are &ldquoextremely hostile to calls from Remainers for another vote on Brexit.He said: &ldquoThey just see it, which it is, an attempt to overturn the original decision. The decision was quite decisive &ndash&nbspnot just in Cleethorpes but through the north of England, in particular.&ldquoThe reality is the legislation said there was a majority decision. Whether it is by one or 1,001, whatever, that would be the decision.&ldquoDavid Cameron made clear that the Government would implement the decision of the referendum and whatever they may say the rebels are trying to thwart the will of the British people.Former head of the civil service Bob Kerslake claimed on Saturday that Britain may have to &ldquopause it&rsquos exit from the EU and &ldquore-examine its decision to leave the bloc if the Government is unable to strike a deal with Brussels.Remainer Lord Kerslake claimed it is &ldquonecessary to delay Brexit and insisted it is &ldquonot too late to &ldquoreopen the question on whether the UK should proceed with Brexit.Speaking on BBC Radio 4&rsquos Today Programme on Saturday, Lord Kerslake said: &ldquoIf the Government can negotiate a good deal then so be it.But if they can&rsquot and we end up in this position then we have to reopen the question of whether we go forward with Brexit at all. It is not too late to do that.Brexit news: Martin Vickers said his constituents are extremely hostile to second referendum (Image: )He added: A pause to reflect would certainly be necessary. I think that is probably a pretty high probability now.But I think that pause would need to include &ndash and I suspect this would be insisted on by the (European) Commission &ndash some re-examination of the decision itself.Prime Minister Theresa May&rsquos Brexit plan, calling for close regulatory alignment with the EU&rsquos single market for British exports, is a firm push towards a soft Brexit.The proposal includes plans to create a common rule book &ndash involving a free trade area with the EU on industrial and agricultural goods.

title: brexit news peoples vote gavin esler scotland remain stop brexit
story: The author and broadcaster accused those pushing for Brexit of deceiving the public.In a fiery speech to campaigners in Edinburgh's Festival Square, Mr Esler insisted a people&rsquos vote on the final deal would &ldquoexpose the hypocrisy of Brexiteers.The event organised by The People's Vote campaign attracted hundreds of people who held banners emblazoned with slogans like Whose deal is it? Let the people choose and We demand a people's vote on the Brexit deal.Mr Esler told the crowd: Truth decay is a rottenness which is undermining our democracy. It has many sources, but one stands out - the Brexit bunch.                Campbell SHUT DOWN as he struggles to give up hope on second vote                Another BREXIT REBELLION: Remainers plan marches for people's voteLike most people in this country, whatever we thought of the vote, I accepted it at first - that's how democracy works.But I've change my mind completely over the last two years of lies and incompetence.Mr Esler has previously grouped leading Brexiteers including Nigel Farage, Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg into his &ldquoBrexit bunch.He went on: The Brexit bunch are the most incompetent bunch of politicians in my lifetime and Brexit is in deep trouble, not because of those of us who thought it was a bad idea, but because those who told us it was a good idea are so incompetent, they don't know what it is.Brexit news: Gavin Esler attacked the 'incompetent Brexit bunch' in a fiery speech (Image: PA)Hundreds of campaigners attended the People's Vote rally in Edinburgh (Image: PA)Support for a public vote on the final Brexit deal is rising in Scotland, polling suggests (Image: PA)Today&rsquos event in Scotland comes as campaigners step up demands for a vote on the final Brexit deal at a time when the country is deeply ided over Theresa May&rsquos blueprint for the split.Critics from both Remain and Leave camps have argued against the Prime Minister&rsquos plan is the worst of all worlds.Those backing a clean break from Brussels have argued the Prime Minister&rsquos plan would keep the UK shackled to the EU for years and prevent it from striking free trade deals around the world.Those intent on remaining in the EU have said the Chequers plan would only serve to give up the UK&rsquos seat at the table while gaining nothing in return.Gavin Esler has previously labelled Boris Johnson part of the 'Brexit bunch' (Image:  IMAGES)In Scotland, support for a vote on the final Brexit deal has grown in recent months, with new polling suggesting nearly two-thirds of Scots believe Westminster is ignoring their concerns during the negotiations.A study carried out for the People&rsquos Vote campaign revealed 66 percent of Scottish voters (excluding don&rsquot knows) now back staying in the EU, compared with 62 percent who voted Remain in the 2016 referendum.The YouGov poll also found 48 percent of those surveyed wanted a public vote on the final deal, compared with 45 percent across the whole of the UK.The poll asked 2,013 adults in Scotland and was carried out during August.

title: hms queen elizabeth aircraft carrier maiden voyage royal navy portsmouth usa
story: The &pound3.1billion behemoth - dubbed &lsquoBig Lizzie&rsquo - set sail from Portsmouth on its way to the United States where warplanes will land on its flight deck for the first time.The two F-35B aircraft, based in Maryland, will touch down on the 65,000-tonne vessel before becoming the first fighters to launch from a British carrier in nearly a decade.While the training jets are the property of the US military, the honour of landing the first one will go to a British pilot.A further 500 test landings and take-offs are expected to take place during HMS Queen Elizabeth&rsquos 11 weeks at sea.HMS Queen Elizabeth set sail from Portsmouth this evening (Image: PA)                Argentinian pilot MOCKED after claiming he 'SUNK' HMS Invincible                UK to send flagship aircraft carrier to ramp up Australian defenceLarge crowds watched on as the carrier made its way out of Portsmouth Naval Base this evening.The vessel is scheduled to carry out tests in UK waters before embarking across the Atlantic.During its time in the US it will visit New York amid rumours President Donald Trump could take a tour.Navy chiefs have pledged the vessel will have the protection needed to counter the eye-watering threat of Russian submarines during its transatlantic trip.HMS Queen Elizabeth is bound for the US where F-35B jets will land on its deck for the first time (Image: PA)The &pound3.1billion aircraft carrier will become the Royal Navy's flagship (Image: PA)Commodore Andrew Betton, commander of the UK Carrier Strike Group, said: Russian submarines are more active in the North Atlantic than they have been since the Cold War and we take that very seriously, the ship will be well protected as she makes her transit across the Atlantic.We will seek to operate professionally and within the standard laws of the high seas operating in international waters going about our business.We are not seeking confrontation, we are heading to the east coast of the United States to conduct trials.Large crowds turned out to see HMS Queen Elizabeth depart Portsmouth Naval Base (Image: PA)Captain Jerry Kyd, the carrier's commanding officer, said: &ldquoThis deployment to the United States will be another first for my ship.&ldquoCrossing a major ocean with 1,500 sailors, aircrew and marines embarked and the spectre of the first F-35B Lightning landing on the deck in September is very exciting for us all.&ldquoIt has been an incredible journey since we left Rosyth just over a year ago and we are all looking forward to this next seminal chapter in HMS Queen Elizabeth's life.HMS Queen Elizabeth will undergo 500 test landings and take offs during her 11-week deployment (Image: PA)Defence secretary Gavin Williamson said the carrier&rsquos voyage to the US will help cement the special relationship with the US as well as demonstrating the vessel&rsquos global reach.He said: HMS Queen Elizabeth is a true statement of our national power and the whole country can be proud to see this magnificent symbol of our engineering prowess and international ambition leaving port to sail on to the world stage.As she sails along the east coast of the USA, she will signal our determination to keep fighting alongside our allies in all corners of an ever more complex and uncertain world.

title: Race against time to save historic Clyde built ship
story: Winter storms could scupper the epic 7,000-mile journey (Image: NC)The Falls of Clyde, the world&rsquos last surviving iron-hulled, four-masted full-rigged ship and the only remaining sail-driven oil tanker, sailed the Pacific for decades before becoming a museum ship in Hawaii.However, she gradually fell into disrepair and her owners announced plans to scuttle the ship in 2008 before agreeing to hand her over to a local charity group, the Friends of the Falls of Clyde.Two years ago, a Scottish sister campaign was launched to bring the windjammer &ndash built by Russell and Company in Port Glasgow in 1878 &ndash back home after 140 years.David O&rsquoNeill, of Save the Falls of Clyde &ndash International, hopes to make an announcement within days about a date for her arrival, possibly the end of September or October.                WWII shipwreck FOUND: Veteran tells his HARROWING story after 75 YEARS                &pound3bn ship will show Russians our mightLast December, a deal was struck with Norwegian heavy lift ship operator OHT to collect Falls of Clyde at a substantially reduced rate with further payment to follow from fundraising &ldquoonce she was home and safe in Scotland.The Hawaiian harbour authorities also agreed to the plan, with OHT suggesting a window of between June and September &ldquowhen the Atlantic weather was more friendly.Then a few months ago the firm decided commercial contracts would have to take precedence over a non-profit operation, leaving campaigners scrambling to find an alternative.Mr O&rsquoNeill said he had secured another &ldquobrilliant deal built around attracting commercial sponsors for the ship&rsquos sails.1895 picture of the Clyde (Image: )He said: &ldquoWe have taken a very unorthodox approach to funding this project and have sought cooperation from the lift ship company by asking them for a fixed date and contract for the operation.&ldquoIn return we have demonstrated we have the means to attract major brand sponsors to the events in Hawaii and on arrival here on the Clyde. We expect that date to be offered soon, after the Hawaiian authorities have confirmed some logistical issues can be overcome locally in Honolulu harbour.&ldquoOur contacts at the Hawaii Pilots Association and tug providers Foss Maritime are engaged in seeking permission to load the ship in harbour. They have suggested permission should be forthcoming as the authorities need our ship gone as they want to commence with rebuilding of Pier 7 as soon as possible.&ldquoTo finance the lift operation we have produced a very innovative approach, borrowing from the various yacht races globally. We have produced a &lsquoFake Sail&rsquo plan to attract commercial sponsors and this includes a full deck awning and even the hull could carry a company name.The River Clyde  (Image:  )Mr O&rsquoNeill added: &ldquoWe expect the lift ship operator to shortly offer a fixed return date, as early as next week, with the ship arriving here around September or October. He said he was in talks with Clydeside councils about organising an escort flotilla, with at least six tall ships, the famous Waverley paddle steamer and numerous sailing and boating clubs expressing an interest.BAE Systems have offered logistical support with unloading the vessel, while a &ldquomajor Glasgow university and Ferguson Marine &ndash the shipyard owned by billionaire Jim McColl &ndash have offered assistance.Paying for the lift ship and the estimated four-year rebuild programme to make her seaworthy again is expected to cost around &pound550,000, with a further fundraising drive set to get under way immediately.Further discussions are ongoing with Peel Ports and Inverclyde Council about a berth at Victoria Harbour in Greenock while she is restored, although alternative locations in Glasgow and Ayrshire are also being considered.

title: Travellers barred from whole towns Draconian laws used in new crackdown
story: The &ldquoblanket injunctions, which mean anyone pulling up on affected sites can be arrested, jailed or fined, can effectively ban travellers from entire boroughs.Councils applying for the orders have given the High Court witness statements and photographs of commercial waste, including asbestos, excrement and damaged locks from vacated sites.Previously, councils have reacted to traveller incursions, but they can now outlaw them before they happen.Nearly 20 authorities across London, Essex, Hampshire, Surrey, the West Midlands and Lancashire now have interim or blanket injunctions, with more believed to be preparing applications.                Traveller crackdown: Tory MPs urge new law to move camps on QUICKLY                Travellers leave rubbish and human FAECES in children's play areaGipsy and traveller organisations have slammed the new power, claiming it will prevent their nomadic way of life.Sarah Sweeney of Friends, Families and Travellers said: &ldquoWe are deeply saddened to hear that increasing numbers of councils are using injunctions to prevent gipsy and traveller families from stopping in their area.&ldquoLocal authorities have largely failed to identify land for families to stop so it should come as little surprise when they pull up in public spaces and on private land.A spokesman for the Community Law Partnership, which has represented travellers for several years, said: &ldquoWe think these wide injunction actions, which are becoming more common, are potentially highly challengeable.Caravans in a M&ampS car park in Camberley, Surrey (Image: STEVE REIGATE)London Borough Sutton is the latest to obtain the power, following a series of costly clean-ups after incursions in recent weeks.The High Court has granted an interim injunction order for three months, banning caravans from 182 sites, before a full application is heard.The injunctions ban named iniduals and &ldquopersons unknown from parking caravans and vehicles and dumping waste in areas they cover.If all councils were granted the power, it could effectively see an end to the bulk of unauthorised camps.Harlow council in Essex, which has two permanent traveller sites, was the first to get the ban, protecting 322 sites, in March 2015, after 109 incursions in 18 months.Council leader Mark Ingall said: &ldquoThis has had the effect of significantly reducing the number and duration of unauthorised encampments and the clean-up costs.It quickly resolves any issues, usually within 24 hours.Basildon in Essex secured one last November and councillor Kevin Blake said: &ldquoThere has been a marked reduction in the number of encampments with no incursions since March this year.20 authorities now have interim or blanket injunctions (Image:  )Greenwich in South-east London now has 203 parks and open spaces protected.A spokeswoman said: &ldquoIt has been hugely successful. There has only been one incursion since the ban was put in place.Redbridge, in east London, saw 40 incursions in 2007.But since securing an interim injunction in June, covering 235 sites, it has seen just one incident on council land, with culprits moved on within two hours, and another on private land.

title: Ben Stokes Trent Bridge fans booed Nottingham third test India
story: His inclusion in the England side just days after being cleared of causing an affray was questioned by some.He has not yet publicly apologised for the late night drinking and fighting that led to his arrest last September.The Durham all-rounder, playing for the first time since his trial at Bristol Crown Court ended on Tuesday, was booed by some sections of the Trent Bridge crowd in Nottingham.Other fans applauded his return to the pitch. Stokes had been accused of knocking out two men outside a Bristol nightclub, but was found not guilty.&nbsp                Ben Stokes recalled by England for third Test against India                Ace Stokes cleared of affrayThe charge saw him miss the Ashes series last winter. Yesterday, in a seven-over spell before lunch, he was not at his best, bowling too short and without his usual venom. He bowled better in the evening session and, while not taking a wicket, took a slip catch to dismiss Indian skipper Virat Kohli for 97. Stokes, 27, was praised for his sportsmanship in apologising to batsman Shikhar Dhawan after colliding with him while going for the ball in a bid to run him out. Dhawan was then seen putting his arm around Stokes&rsquos shoulder in a good-natured embrace. Before the Test started Kohli warmly greeted the fiery allrounder, shaking his hand.&nbspLIGHT RELIEF: Stokes is embraced by batsman Dhawan after the two collided (Image: PA )NOT GUILTY: Stokes and wife Clare after the court case (Image: PA)Surrey all-rounder Sam Curran, 20, man of the match in the first Test, lost his place and a debate raged on social media as to the fairness of the decision. Some took issue with the decision to invite Stokes to join the squad days after his trial. Ian posted on Twitter: &ldquoAll the debate on who should have been dropped for Stokes completely misses the point that Ben Stokes should not have been picked. &ldquoHe hasn&rsquot even the decency to apologise. Shame on the selectors &amp England and Wales Cricket Board. Ruth Brooksbank said: &ldquoNothing special from Ben Stokes yet. Dare I suggest that sitting in the dock probably wasn&rsquot the ideal prep for a Test Match?

title: Universities offer free travel and cash to lure in students
story: Nearly 5,000 places are still up for grabs at some of the best universities (Image: )Competition among institutions has become fierce this year with a fall in the number of people applying for undergraduate courses.As a result teenagers going through clearing have more than 30,000 courses to choose from.Nearly 5,000 places are still up for grabs at some of the best universities in the UK.Last night clearing staff were tempting students with cash awards and other goodies.                'University grants should be brought back to give disadvantaged a f...                Fears of fall in A-Level resultsThe University of Westminster was offering 60 scholarships worth &pound1,500 per year for three years (Image: )Leicester University was pledging to give money to charity for every student that came to it through clearing.It said: &ldquoIf you&rsquove accepted an offer with us today you&rsquore making an out-of-this-world difference.For every undergraduate student that enrols we&rsquoll make a donation to local charity Leicester Bridge in the form of space blankets and other essentials.Swansea University said the campus was &ldquoright by a beach, while Greenwich was offering free Tube, bus and rail passes around London.Queen&rsquos University Belfast pointed out that it was the &ldquoUK&rsquos safest region.The University of Westminster was offering 60 scholarships worth &pound1,500 per year for three years to clearing applicants who achieve at least one grade above the published standard entry requirement for their course, while Sussex University was guaranteeing accommodation on campus.Professor Alan Smithers, director of the Centre for Education and Employment at Buckingham University, said: &ldquoThe higher education system has over-expanded so universities are in the position of supermarkets who have ordered too much in.&ldquoThey are using whatever tactics they can to shift the places.Spending probably more than they can afford in advertising, letting students in with low grades and using all kinds of incentives to sign up.If students are lured in they are more likely to drop out, wasting their money and taxpayers&rsquo money.                University isn&rsquot for everyone ...so keep calm and consider all options                Growing FEARS about &lsquounconditional&rsquo university offersLast night clearing staff were tempting students with cash awards and other goodies (Image: )Professor Alan Smithers, director of the Centre for Education and Employment at Buckingham University, said: &ldquoThe higher education system has over-expanded so universities are in the position of supermarkets who have ordered too much in.&ldquoThey are using whatever tactics they can to shift the places.Spending probably more than they can afford in advertising, letting students in with low grades and using all kinds of incentives to sign up.If students are lured in they are more likely to drop out, wasting their money and taxpayers&rsquo money.

title: A church on every estate
story: The project is backed by the Archbishop of Canterbury (Image: )A church on every estate in the UK is the ambitious new vision of the Church of England.The project, backed by the Archbishop of Canterbury, will see residents on large estates receive help to set up and lead the new churches.It aims to bring Christianity and church life to communities which might not otherwise attend standard services &ndash and help tackle the rise in violent crime.Community centres, cafes and schools will be used as bases for worshippers to meet.                Fury as Archbishop of Canterbury hails European Union in new speech                 Archbishop of Canterbury says HIGHER taxes should fund NHS Thriving church estates have already sprung up around the UK and church leaders say they build stronger communities.The Bishop of Burnley, Philip North, chairman of the Archbishops&rsquo Estates Evangelism Task Force, said: &ldquoThe vision is a thriving, loving Christian church on every single large estate. &ldquoThat&rsquos not a building &ndash we&rsquore talking about church as community of people.&ldquoSometimes it will be in a church building, but often it might be in a community centre or in a school or a large cafe. &ldquoThat&rsquos the vision a thriving Christian community on every estate.Estate residents will be trained to lead the churches, including the possibility of ordination.The project is part of the CofE&rsquos expecting people to come to us but for us to go to them.Bishop North believes the presence of a church on an estate can address the issue of violent crime by creating strong communities. &ldquoWhat the church does best is to build community and to build places where you can form a safe relationship.&ldquoWe can&rsquot solve those big cultural problems, but what we can do is offer iniduals spaces of safety and belonging where they can turn their lives around. That&rsquos where local churches are at their best.&ldquoWe talk the language of hope and we can answer some of these questions.People from all backgrounds can lead on estates, but if you want to plant a new church, that&rsquos best  (Image: )Bishop Thorpe said: &ldquoChurches on estates are close to those who live on estates.They are often the first to know about issues with young people and support young people. &ldquoAs Christians, we believe that God wants everyone to discover a relationship with him through Jesus Christ.So we need to go to every place, which includes places that many people don&rsquot go to, like estates.Speaking about one successful estate church in the north of England, Bishop North said: &ldquoOne of the key leaders in that church was addicted to heroin for 23 years and he gave it up when he found this church.&ldquoI asked him why and he said, &lsquoBecause I found somewhere where I felt safe&rsquo.You&rsquore seeing lives turned round and that&rsquos very exciting for church leaders.Renewal and Reform strategy.Bishop North said: &ldquoThe best person to plant a church on an estate is someone from that estate.                Demise of Christianity: Haunting pictures show abandoned churches                The vicar's wife secret affair forced them to quitPeople from all backgrounds can lead on estates, but if you want to plant a new church, that&rsquos best done by a local person.&ldquoIt&rsquos about identifying local leaders with those skills and training them up. We&rsquore encouraging churches to identify local people from estates with the skills to plant new churches.&ldquoThe Archbishop of Canterbury started an Evangelism Task Group about five or six years ago.We have said that this will only work if we are serious about the urban church and what&rsquos going on the estates.&ldquoA church which abandons poor areas is not the church of Jesus Christ.So we worked very hard to get that &lsquoestates voice&rsquo heard. &ldquoArchbishop was very, very up for that and really understood what we were saying.The Bishop of Islington, Ric Thorpe, is leading a project to grow new churches in London.Bishop North believes the presence of a church on an estate can address the issue of violent crime  (Image: )He said: &ldquoCouncil estates are places that are sometimes cut off from the rest of a parish.Where a couple of generations ago people attended the local church from the estate, now less and less attend.&ldquoRather than expecting them to come to the parish church, we should go to them.Bishop Thorpe, who is on the team of Capital Vision 2020 &ndash creating 100 new worshipping communities by 2020 &ndash added: &ldquoThis is the call of the church through the ages, like the incarnation of Jesus, not expecting people to come to us but for us to go to them.Bishop North believes the presence of a church on an estate can address the issue of violent crime by creating strong communities.&ldquoWhat the church does best is to build community and to build places where you can form a safe relationship. &ldquoWe can&rsquot solve those big cultural problems, but what we can do is offer iniduals spaces of safety and belonging where they can turn their lives around. That&rsquos where local churches are at their best.&ldquoWe talk the language of hope and we can answer some of these questions.Bishop Thorpe said: &ldquoChurches on estates are close to those who live on estates.They are often the first to know about issues with young people and support young people.&ldquoAs Christians, we believe that God wants everyone to discover a relationship with him through Jesus Christ.So we need to go to every place, which includes places that many people don&rsquot go to, like estates. Speaking about one successful estate church in the north of England, Bishop North said: &ldquoOne of the key leaders in that church was addicted to heroin for 23 years and he gave it up when he found this church.&ldquoI asked him why and he said, &lsquoBecause I found somewhere where I felt safe&rsquo.You&rsquore seeing lives turned round and that&rsquos very exciting for church leaders.

title: BBC Weather forecast news Met Office heatwave London latest next week storm Ernesto
story: BBC Weather warned Storm Ernesto could cause parts of Britain to be hit with gale force winds over the weekend.BBC Weather meteorologist Alina Jenkins said: &ldquoThis is the remnants of what was ex-tropical Storm Ernesto. That will pep up the rain overnight. For much of England Wales through this after &ndash although a lot of clouds it should be mainly dry.&ldquoThe odd spot of rain perhaps for parts of Wales and south west England. The far north of Scotland sunny spells and a few showers. Some sunshine getting across to eastern parts of Scotland too.&ldquoBut it&rsquos the western isles of Scotland which will continue to see some stronger gusts &ndash&nbspgale force for a time &ndash and also quite gusty winds along western and channel coasts through this afternoon.                BBC Weather warn tropical Storm Ernesto will pound Britain                UK weather: Met Office weather map reveals where Ernesto will hitOn Saturday night the remnants of ex-tropical storm Ernesto will become more apparent with &ldquopersistent spell of rain arriving in Northern Ireland, north Wales, northern England and central parts of Scotland.Ernesto, which formed in the mid-Atlantic, is described as a post-tropical cyclone &ndash a weather pattern which can bring property-threatening 40mph winds and drenching downpours.The powerful wind created by the storm also harnesses enough power to create damage roofs and bring down power lines.Weather experts advise to make sure all loose objects outside are secured and to postpone any unnecessary trips as the strong winds will make driving hazardous.The BBC forecaster said that further south it will be dry but a &ldquowarm and muggy night.Sunday afternoon is mostly dry.The BBC forecaster said: &ldquoAcross much of England and Wales it is another very humid feeling day. Temperatures up to 23 or 24C. Cooler and fresher for the far north of Scotland.She added: &ldquoAs you go into the new working week fronts pushing their way eastwards but leaving a legacy of cloud.&ldquoAnd this front will continue to generate further shower outbreaks of rain across parts of Scotland, Northern Ireland and some of those showers likely to extend their way down into parts of Northern England.&ldquoHead further south and it is mainly dry. Again, quite a bit of cloud but we should see bright and sunny spells through the afternoon.BBC Weather forecast temperatures will pick up in the UK next week  (Image: WXCHARTS)&ldquoWe are still holding on to that warmth and humidity, particularly across England and Wales with temperatures here getting up to 25C.Temperatures could reach as high as 26C in London while Cardiff is at 21C and Edinburgh 19C.The Met Office revealed that temperatures could soar even further next week as a change in the jet stream threatens a huge shake-up in the weather system once again.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern warned there is &ldquohuge uncertainty about the weather in Britain next week, with either the possibility of more unsettled and rainy conditions or scorching heatwave temperatures.BBC weather forecast: Temperatures expected to hit 26C in London on Monday (Image: BBC&bull)Speaking in the Met Office 10 day weather forecast, Mr McGivern said: Computer simulations are picking up on something that is just happening thousands of miles away over to the west of the North American continent.&ldquoThe big ridge in the jet stream here could start to happen and if that happens then it will have big downstream consequences on the weather at home because this ridge will then ripple all the way across North America, the&nbspnorth&nbspAtlantic and then under close to the UK.&ldquoIf we end up on the south of this ridge we will have similar weather to what we had earlier in the summer &ndash the heatwave, the dry, the heat, the high pressure.&ldquoBut if we end up for the north of the jet stream we will end up with&nbspvery&nbspunsettled weather.

title: Uk weather forecast tonight storm ernesto path latest met office bbc weather
story: UK weather forecast: Ernesto to ENGULF parts of UK in WILDFIRE SMOKE                BBC Weather forecast: GALE FORCE winds to hit UK before heatwave The post-tropical cyclone's circulation should dissipate while it moves across Ireland and portions of the United Kingdom by early Sunday.The UK Met Office warned parts of Britain are likely to see an &lsquoawful lot of rainfall&rsquo overnight and into tomorrow.Meteorologist Aidan McGivern said the next few days will be warm and muggy as the remains of Ernesto blanket the nation.He said: &ldquoAn area of rainfall is approaching from the Atlantic and that carries with it an awful lot of rain.UK weather: Storm Ernesto will hit Ireland at 8pm before heading to Britain (Image: NOOA)                UK weather WARNING: Brutal tropical storm to smash Britain in 24 hours                UK weather 2018: How the weather can make you SICK revealedThe mercury will widely rise into the high 20Cs this afternoon with the south remaining warm and muggy for the next five days at least.Above-average temperatures are widely forecast through the first half of next week although it will be warmest in southern England, experts say.The blue skies and sunshine of the past few months are not expected to make a return however with a grey, cloudy, humid outlook on the cards.Met Office meteorologist Emma Smith warned muggy conditions will hold out over the next few nights with temperatures unlikely to dip below 18C (64.4F) in parts.She said: &ldquoWe could see temperatures of 26C (78.8F) in the south on Sunday with northern England at around 22C (71.6F) or 23C (73.4F).&ldquoTemperatures are unlikely to drop out of the high teens overnight so it will be uncomfortable for sleeping.&ldquoThe warm and humid conditions will last until the middle of next week when there are signs it will turn fresher.Western Britain will be in the firing line for winds tonight with the heaviest downpours expected across central England and Cumbria, she added.UK weather latest: Storm Ernesto's path latest shows it heading to Britain (Image: NOAA)She said: &ldquoThe remnants of Ernesto are with a low-pressure system moving towards Ireland at the moment.&ldquoThere will be some heavy outbreaks of rain in Scotland, northern England and Wales later tonight with the heaviest downpours across the central belt of Britain, here we could see 50mm.&ldquoThere will also be strong winds along the Irish sea coasts which will affect the western coast of Britain through tonight.&ldquoThe system will clear quite readily tomorrow morning however it will leave a pattern of cloudy weather behind it.UK weather: Ernesto's path shows when it will hit Britain (Image: NOAA)&ldquoFor many places it is going to be grey.As Ernesto prepares to launch its assault on Britain bookies have slashed the odds on the ex-storm bringing record rainfall.Coral is offering 3-1 from 5-1 on this month ending up the wettest August on record while it is 6-4 we will still see the record UK temperature of 38.5C (101.3F) fall before the end of summer.Spokesman John Hill said: &ldquoStorm Ernesto is expected to bring some torrential downpours with it therefore the odds have been cut on this month ending as the wettest August on record.&ldquoAlthough we are set for a wet few days, the temperatures are still going to rise therefore we remain very much on course for the hottest ever summer in the UK.                Solar storm forecast: NASA spots GIANT coronal hole in surface of Sun                BBC Weather warn tropical Storm Ernesto will pound BritainNetweather forecaster Nick Finnis said Britain&rsquos weather will be influenced by Atlantic low pressure into next week.He said: &ldquoThis weekend our weather will be coming in off the Atlantic, so unfortunately it will be on the cloudy side, with the addition of an ex-tropical storm named Ernesto in the mix &ndash which will bring wet and windy weather tonight into Sunday morning, the rain mostly across northern Britain.&ldquoIt will feel humid across the south though, as we draw in tropical air ahead of ex-Ernesto, and if the sun comes out across the south &ndash it will feel rather warm.&ldquoThe changeable conditions off the Atlantic will continue next week, often breezy, but most of the rain across the north just briefly affecting the south perhaps on Thursday, where the sun comes out it will feel warm in the south.

title: UK weather forecast tropical storm ernesto met office weather latest
story: The storm will begin tracking across Northern Ireland, northern England and southern Scotland during the early hours of Sunday morning.&nbspBy mid-morning these areas are expected to be hit with torrential rain, whilst strong winds batter the coasts of Wales and south west England.&nbspAccording to Met Office meteorologist Becky Mitchell the north of England &ldquocould easily see 10 to 20 millimetres of rain.&nbspHowever parts of Cumbria should expect &ldquoquite a bit more.&nbsp                UK weather: Heatwave to RETURN next week with 28C SCORCHER                UK weather ALERT: Tropical Storm Ernesto to SMASH into Britain TONIGHTErnesto, now described as a post-tropical cyclone, was created in the Atlantic and has been heading east.&nbspPost-tropical cyclones can see winds of 40mph, enough to damage roofs and bring down power lines, as well as torrential downpours.&nbspThe advice in such conditions is to ensure all loose objects are secured and avoid travelling unless strictly necessary, as windy conditions could make the roads dangerous.&nbspBy early afternoon the heaviest rain should have subsided, and post-tropical Storm Ernesto will be steered east into the North sea by a low-pressure system.&nbspThe north of England &ldquocould easily see 10 to 20 millimetres of rain.  (Image: THE MET OFFICE)Ms Mitchell explains that in northern England and southern Scotland: &ldquoby the afternoon we are left with a good deal of cloud, some light outbreaks of drizzle here and there.&ldquoBut eventually possibly some brighter spells breaking through that cloud at times.The best of the sunshine on Sunday afternoon will be in Northern Ireland, which Storm Ernesto will have passed by this point, and north west Scotland.&nbspThe bright conditions will push into other western areas on Sunday evening, as Ernesto moves further east.&nbspIn the afternoon the south of England will encounter warm and humid conditions.&nbspIn this part of the county, temperatures could reach 24 or 25 degrees.&nbsp&ldquoby the afternoon we are left with a good deal of cloud, some light outbreaks of drizzle (Image:  )In the afternoon the south of England will encounter warm and humid conditions.&nbspIn this part of the county, temperatures could reach 24 or 25 degrees.&nbspSunday is expected to be largely dry.&nbspNext week will see the warm weather return.&nbspStorm Ernesto was created in the Atlantic and has been heading east  (Image: MET OFFICE)According to Ms Mitchell: &ldquoThe start of next week stays pretty warm and humid for the bulk of the UK.&nbsp&ldquoTemperatures could reach the high 20C&rsquos on Tuesday and Wednesday.&nbsp&ldquoBut fresh air is never far away and eventually towards the end of the week temperatures will return back towards average.&nbsp

title: university isnt the only option for a level students
story: After two years of studying for A-levels, thousands of young people will find out if their hard work has paid off.Whether they’re aiming to start an apprenticeship, take a place at university, or go straight into a good job, there are plenty of opportunities awaiting them – and the prospects are high.The jobs market has transformed since 2010, with over 3.3 million more people in work – on average that’s over 1,000 more people in a job each and every day.And, since 2010, the majority of that employment growth has been in both full-time and permanent roles.Only yesterday, the latest official statistics showed that unemployment has fallen to 4% - which means it’s the lowest it’s been since the 1970s.To put that into context, someone would be well into their 50s today to remember a time of lower unemployment.And this transformation of the jobs landscape is being led by our young people. Yesterdays employment figures revealed that the proportion of young people unemployed (and not in full-time education) is now at a record low of 4.7% for our country - and far lower than for many other developed countries.It sends a significant message out about the drive and innovation of our young people, and the opportunities that our economy offers to them and their future.With our welfare changes this country can now be powered forward by this young generation.Since 2010, youth unemployment has fallen by over 45%, giving 130,000 more young people a job, and a future.Add the fact that wages are on the up and there are more than 829,000 vacancies nationwide, it’s clear that young people are entering the best jobs market in a decade.On average, the number of vacancies has increased by 4,280 each month over the last year, and those vacancies span from construction to technology.So when young people this week are deciding on their next steps, they can think big as there are plenty of opportunities out there for them, from a job with career progression, to taking up an apprenticeship.Look at Daisy, who turned down five university offers to work at global engineering firm JCB designing new equipment, and she didn’t have to go to university to get there.I’m forever being told, and intrinsically understand, that people want to study at different times in their lives, often inspired to do so when they see the practical benefits of their studies.That’s why so many people prefer, and do better, getting a job first and then studying for exams while they work.Even over the last few decades, how the world of education and work are linked has shifted dramatically. People no longer have one job for life, and lifelong learning is becoming more and more commonplace as people dip in and out of education.Many more people up-skill and retrain throughout their career – and this is how the future jobs market will remain vibrant and strong.And when I speak to employers up and down the country, from manufacturers to marketers, what they want are young people with the right attitude, prepared to work and learn. As they say, ‘if you’ve the will, we can give you the skill’.So when young people this week are deciding their next steps, the academic route isn’t the only option.You can now become a solicitor, an accountant or even a nuclear engineer through the apprenticeship route, earning as you learn and without the cost of going to University. Studying a Higher Apprenticeship gives an average wage boost of £150,000 over a working life.When I speak to young people around the country, I’m impressed with the confidence and self-assuredness with which they look to the future, and the range of options they consider beyond traditional routes.Im certainly no job snob. Life teaches you its not where you come from, its where you get to, and work is exactly the same.You can start anywhere and get to the top as Im repeatedly being told by our countrys top entrepreneurs.Top performers in their fields such as Debbie Moore, Jean-Christophe Novelli, Deborah Meaden and Jo Malone, did not go to university and are just a handful of the individuals who show that with drive and determination you can succeed by treading your own path.Its all about getting a break and taking the opportunities that come your way.So best of luck to everyone today, but whatever your results, there are many opportunities and pathways into a successful career.    Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we are finally showing brussels we can go it alone after brexit and not before time
story: The publication of “technical notices” outlining how life will continue more or less as normal if the EU refuses to do a deal with Britain for petty political reasons is a crucial boost to our negotiating hand.Compare this grown-up approach to what Brussels and some European leaders have been up to recently.The EU has accused MI6 of bugging our Brexit talks. And our “ally” across the Irish Sea, the rent-a-quote Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, is threatening to ground our planes the day we leave.The silly season is coming to an end but it seems only Britain is getting serious.There is still much to do if, as we suspect, Brussels has no interest in negotiating in good faith. They are so terrified by the collapse of their project, thanks to unrest everywhere from Italy to Poland, that they’re willing to make themselves poorer as a result.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab must get his department moving quicker and force other parts of government to speed up their preparation.But we are finally showing we can go it alone. Not before time.AMAZON appear to be launching another front in their all-out war to take over just about every bit of our lives, with plans for a comparison site.This doesn’t fill us with excitement. After all, in recent days we’ve learnt that Brits are being charged over the odds for their Prime subscriptions, a service which itself has been shown not to deliver on its “next day” promises.We’ve no problem with competition or businesses doing well. Good companies with good profits create good jobs.But they must play by the rules, especially when other firms — such as high street retailers — are struggling.It is still staggering to us that Amazon’s UK tax bill FELL last year despite it almost tripling its profits.The Chancellor must close the costly loopholes that tech giants continue to exploit.WE’RE saying a little prayer for the Queen of Soul.Aretha Franklin redefined the music landscape, her songs influencing everybody from Luther Vandross to Adele.But she also raised huge amounts of money for the civil rights struggle in the US, doing it not for publicity but because she believed in it.Her extraordinary take on Otis Redding’s Respect became an anthem not just for African Americans but for feminists the world over.Rest in peace.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madonna best at being madge
story: She might have had a bit of assistance to retain such a fresh-faced youthfulness, but the body is all her own work.Through hours of  gym graft and sheer willpower she’s even more bendy now than when she first burst on to the scene back in 1984 warbling Holiday in a Minnie Mouse falsetto.Madonna is the biggest-selling female artist ever, shifting 300million albums and is worth around 454million quid.She’s achieved success on her own terms and been a trailblazer for every other successful female act following in her wake. There would be no Katy Perry, Miley Cyrus or arguably Lady Gaga without Madonna.She might not be the best singer or dancer in the world, but she’s certainly the best at just being Madonna.You simply can’t imagine anyone ever telling her what to do. She’d laugh in their face.Madonna had always known how to grab attention, whether it’s publishing a book stuffed full of naked photos of herself, faking self-pleasure on stage, or kissing Britney Spears.And only Madonna could have bounced back from almost being strangled by her bright red Armani cape when she took a tumble and fell on her backside during the Brit Awards three years ago.She merely dusted herself down and carried on regardless, but I bet whoever was in charge of her wardrobe that night would have been given the b******ing of their life.Madonna is always in charge, professionally and personally. Even during her brief fling with aging lothario Warren Beatty, he was very much a bit player in the Madonna Show.That must have badly bruised the ego of a man who had always had the upper-hand in his relationships until then.It has to be said her love life hasn’t been anywhere near as successful as her career.There was a brief, destructive marriage to American actor Sean Penn in the Eighties and in 2000 she married Guy Ritchie, but the couple divorced eight years later.Since then she has dated a string of handsome and often young men, but they usually seemed to have the whiff of a photo opportunity about them rather than anything long term.She chews them up, spits them out and moves on to the next one.Madonna seems happiest as a single mum.She has uprooted the family to Lisbon, in Portugal,  because her adopted son David wants to play professional football.With her vast wealth she could easily have bought him a team such as LA Galaxy but she has always had a Calvinistic work ethic that she has tried to pass on to her kids.She has also made up with son Rocco Ritchie after a bitter custody battle and appears to be in a very good place.In an era where most young female vocalists all sound the same — bored, whiny and more than a wee bit yodelly — we really do need a one-off like Madonna.I hope she had a fabulous birthday on Thursday in Marrakech, Morocco, and danced until dawn to all of her greatest hits.Happy 60th birthday, ma’am, and I’ve no doubt you will still be in your fishnets and basques when you get that 100-year birthday message.Just when the royals and their advisers thought the whole fiasco between Meghan Markle and her dad had gone quiet, there comes a bizarre twist.Meghan’s rent-a-gob half-sister Samantha, who seethes with rage and jealousy, has announced that Thomas Markle is bringing out his own clothing range.This led to speculation as to what the brand might be called.  “Markle &amp Spencer” or “Primarkles”  (thank you, Alan Carr). But joking aside, surely this can’t be a serious  concept.Apart from being a crass, money-grabbing exercise cashing in on a quasi-royal connection, who on earth would buy garments from a pensioner who dresses like a hobo?I’ve had a great deal of sympathy for Thomas  in the past. He was treated poorly in the build-up to the  Royal Wedding, when his daughter married Prince Harry.He should have been embraced by his new family and given guidance on how to deal with the  media attention.Instead he was cast adrift. The result? Those stupid paparazzi set-up photos and a series of interviews that painted Meghan in a poor light.Every time her dad talks on TV or to newspapers and magazines, her popularity is dented.The two of them obviously have a fraught relationship. It turns out Thomas didn’t attend Meghan’s first wedding in 2011 either.Thomas increasingly comes across as bitter, angry and dislikable.To gain media attention he keeps making more and more outrageous accusations.My advice would be to stop listening to his bitchy daughter Samantha and maintain a dignified silence.All thoughts of profiteering through a clothing range or any commercial activity must be abandoned forthwith.That just might mean there could be some  sort of reconciliation in the future.Otherwise he will lose his daughter forever.ONE of the week’s most astonishing stories involved a young US woman who has been given her life back with a groundbreaking face transplant.Three years ago, Katie Stubblefield, from Mississippi in the US, tried to take her own life and shot herself in the face with a hunting rifle. She was just 18.Doctors saved her life but she was left with a mass of scar tissue instead of a face.Katie, the youngest person ever to receive a face transplant, endured more than 30 hours of surgery.Of course, the operation requires a donor – and in this case it is  a very sad story.Katie received the face  of a mum who died of a drug overdose.She was a registered organ donor and her grandmother bravely approved the donation.That decision can’t have been easy and we should always salute those who are donors, and the loved ones who give their consent.Katie won’t look like anything like her donor because the “face” is moulded on to her new bone structure.She continues to heal and  make progress, but this kind of surgery is still in its infancy.She will always look “different” but she has a second chance of life and now wants to help others in anguish and with suicidal thoughts.It’s an incredible story of despair that turned to  hope.  The skill and dedication of the team of surgeons and medics that helped her is awe-inspiring.I’m always surprised to learn that Caroline Flack is 38 years old.The presenter looks a  lot younger – and at the moment she is acting like a lovesick teenager going through the agony and ecstasy of her first serious crush.Her off/on romance with red carpet fever victim Andrew Brady is becoming laughable.This week the couple apparently had yet another spat in a London ­restaurant.If these two are to have any chance of staying together long term, they need to get out of the public eye and spend some quiet time alone.I’m sure Caroline knows of a certain Love Island that isn’t being used right now. That would do very well.The ending of the second series of The Handmaid’s Tale had me shouting in despair at my TV.I don’t want to give away too many spoilers but this cliffhanger will break your heart.It also, however, sets up season three for long overdue revenge.As always, astonishing performances from Elisabeth Moss as  June/Ofglen and Yvonne Strahovski as Serena Joy.They will soon fight it out for real when the TV actress awards are up for grabs.I’ve lost track of the amount of slippers our border terrier puppy Angus has chewed up, but this week he surpassed himself by getting his paws on his Pet Passport and virtually destroying it when we were in Spain.Luckily a  local vet issued him with a Spanish version and he now boasts dual nationality.He’s suddenly developed a liking for an afternoon siesta, but at least we were able to get him back into the UK – although who knows what will happen to him after Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: public realised leopard corbyn spots
story: If Corbyn wishes to deny the obvious that is his prerogative the notion you should be prepared to swallow any and every piece of whitewashing nonsense peddled by his fans is quite a different matter.“I was present” when the wreath was laid “but I don’t think I was involved in it” is, I suppose, a step forward from the Labour party’s previous suggestion that “The Munich widows are being misled. Jeremy did not honour those responsible for the Munich killings”.Holding a wreath should not be reckoned to be any kind of endorsement of the wreath we know Jeremy deplores this kind of thing and, indeed, all other forms of wreath.Hark, though, at how quickly the approved line may shift. What was a “smear” yesterday is a forgotten truth today, airbrushed from history because, well, that’s the way these people do these things.The new line is Jeremy wants to see “a fitting memorial to everyone who died in every terrorist incident everywhere”.I dare say he’ll be visiting Enniskillen soon. Of course.And yet, in one sense there really isn’t very much to look at. Or, rather, very little that is new. This is who Corbyn is and who he has always been.He has never bothered hiding this, leaving one to assume he only does so now because there is some small, nagging part of his brain which accepts it might be sensible to do so, since failing to hide it might prove politically inconvenient.Even so, he cannot change. Anyone who has been at university will recognise Corbyn and all his fellow travellers.These were the people — some of them clever but not many of them intelligent — who fouled student politics for everyone else.The chiselling parsers and pedants and revolutionaries whose appetite for procedural minutiae bored everyone else into submission.And usually that would be that. They would, most of them, grow up eventually. But not St Jeremy and not his devotional disciples, either.They are greyer now but as instantly recognisable as they always were: Experts in room-clearing.They ought, by rights, to be confined to dingy rooms above down-at-heel pubs, where they could cut and paste their thuddingly dreary newsletters. Instead, mystifyingly, they have been given control of one of Britain’s great political parties.How much will this summer of anti-Semitism really cut through with the average voter? Less than you might think, I suspect.In the first place — and this may be a good thing — Twitter remains a niche platform and political Twitter a niche even there.Secondly, the public have already made up their minds about Corbyn and they think he’s a dud.Each month YouGov asks whether Jeremy Corbyn or Theresa May seems the best available Prime Minister and each month Corbyn trails.Sometimes he is also beaten by “Don’t know”. That’s Corbyn: He can come third in a two-horse race.But, they splutter, look at what a kind and gentle and decent man he is. Why can’t other people see that he’s a valiant activist for peace?Possibly because, for a decent fellow, he spends a startling amount of time with thoroughly indecent people.He keeps falling in with the wrong crowd while never being a member of the wrong crowd himself. There is no need here to document the long list of unsavoury people with whom Corbyn has been happy to associate himself because, really, what is now the point? He is who he is and we know who he is.In Corbyn’s world every-thing has a single, simple explanation. Colonialism is the root cause of all root causes.That insight — if we can call it that — dictated his views on Ireland just as it dictates his views on the Middle East, Cuba, Venezuela and everywhere else.From there it is but a short leap to the kind of deluded wishful thinking that animates what passes for his thinking. Once you have assumed that Northern Ireland should not exist, you absolve yourself of any and all need to think about what should happen next.You may ignore the inconvenient, and stubborn, reality that Northern Ireland — like, well, Israel — does exist and is not going to disappear.Practical politics means wrestling with things as they are, not as you think they should have been decades previously.But if you start with the theory, you may avoid practical reality. If this leaves you with nothing — precisely nothing — useful to say then so be it. You will at least remain pure in heart.If this means you are no kind of “peace campaigner” at all, that’s fine too, because you will be shielded by your own impenetrable sanctimony.As poses go, this is an awfully comfortable one but it’s not serious politics.Perhaps Corbyn really is just unlucky. But it seems more probable that he’s not. And that, far from being the decent man of legend he’s actually thoroughly indecent.The only possible alternative is that he’s thunderously, crushingly, toe-curlingly thick.On balance, however, it seems more probable that he is, in fact, both.Enough of this. Enough, already.GOT a story? RING The Sun on 0207 782 4104 or WHATSAPP on 07423720250 or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: putin dances austria foreign minister wedding
story: The president controversially received an invitation that opposition critics said undermined the Wests stance against Moscow.Putin arrived in a car carrying a bouquet of flowers and accompanied, local media said, by a troupe of Cossack singers booked to serenade the newlyweds.This was on a stopover on his way to meet German Chancellor Angela Merkel outside Berlin.Photographs showed Kneissl, 53, smiling in a long white and cream dirndl dress and talking to Putin as they danced in a vineyard in southern Styria province, the venue of her wedding to entrepreneur Wolfgang Meilinger.The invitation surprised many in Vienna and Moscow, particularly at a time when the European Union is at odds with Russia over its annexation of Ukraines Crimea region and other issues.There have been no reports that Kneissl - a polyglot Middle East expert without political affiliation - has a particularly close friendship with Putin. But she was appointed to her job by the far-right Freedom Party (FPO) which has links with Putins party.FPO leader and Vice Chancellor Heinz-Christian Strache, who joined Austrias governing coalition last year, praised her as a bridge builder as he congratulated the couple and wished them all the luck in the world and eternal love!The international coverage of the visit would bring priceless publicity, he added. A better advertisement for Austria, it’s wonderful nature, dreamlike landscape and real life hospitality cannot exist!Joerg Leichtfried from the opposition Social Democrats tweeted that Austrias current presidency of the Council of the European Union put it in an especially delicate spot given tensions between Putin and the West.All the more symbolic and harmful to court the Russian president in this manner, he said.Austrias governing coalition - led by the conservatives of Chancellor Sebastian Kurz, who also attended the wedding - has presented itself as a bridge builder with Moscow.It says it shares the EUs foreign policy stance, but did not follow other members of the bloc in expelling Russian diplomats after Britain accused Russia of involvement in the poisoning of a former Russian spy and his daughter in England - a charge Moscow denies.Putin is due to travel to Germany later on Saturday to meet Chancellor Angela Merkel for talks about Syria, Ukraine and energy at the governments Meseberg palace outside Berlin.

title: rose west pampered behind bars
story: The 64-year-old was said to have completed ­sewing tasks for other cons.She even put up a sign outside, proudly saying “Threads”.But the inmate changed it to read “Freds” — after Rose’s late serial killer husband Fred West.The couple were responsible for the murder and torture of ten women in their house of horrors in Gloucester.But the lag said Rose was treated like a celeb by staff in HMP Durham — before both were switched to HMP Low Newton.Ex-con Katherine Jones, 52, said: “It made me sick to see how much they pampered this vile monster.“The staff gave her a little office on the wing and she put up a sign saying ‘Threads’.“But I changed it to ‘Fred’s’ — I don’t think she was happy about it. I used to shout down the wing, ‘Rose West’! She’d say, ‘Yes’? And I’d yell, ‘Fred wants ya’!”Katherine, from Liverpool, had been serving life in jail for murder, but was released last month.She added: “Doing time alongside Rose West was my punishment. I’m so glad I’ll never have to see her evil face again.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
