title: meghan markle reveals four words
story: NewsMeghan Markle reveals the four words dad Thomas said that 'will stay with her forever'The now Duchess of Sussex has also told of the heartwarming Christmas gift her father gave her as a child - and the only time she ever saw him so enraged it made his 'eyes pop'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmber Hicks18:30, 18 AUG 2018Updated19:07, 18 AUG 2018NewsThomas was Meghan's biggest supporterGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Meghan Markle and her 74-year-old father's volatile relationship has taken another battering after he likened the Royal Family to a cult last night.   The close and unrequited bond the pair once had now appears to be in tatters as Thomas Markle and Meghan's half-sister Samantha take it in turns to make public digs at Meghan, her husband Prince Harry and the Royal Family .  Meghan, however, has kept a dignified silence - and reportedly not spoken to her father since her wedding almost three months ago. But in a fresh outburst yesterday Mr Markle said of the Royal Family: “They are cult-like —– like Scientology — because they are secretive.  They close the door, pull the shades down and put their fingers in their ears so they don’t have to hear.  However before the now Duchess of Sussex, 37, met Harry she lovingly described Mr Markle as the most hardworking father you can imagine.  She laid bare her love for the man who always believed she would be a success and who made sacrifices so she could fulfill her dream of becoming an actress. She also told of the heartwarming Christmas gift her father gave her as a child, which she pictured him getting glares for from mums. And the only time she ever saw him so enraged it made his 'eyes pop'. Meghan has also revealed the four words her father told her that will stay with her forever: “Draw your own box.” It was after Meghan came home one day from school upset.  Recalling the incident, she says she had to fill out a census form before an English exam and tick whether she was white, black, Hispanic or Asian. Being biracial - with a Caucasian father and a African American mother - she didn't know which box she fitted into, so out of confusion and sadness she left it blank. When she told her father what happened she admits she had never seen him angry before, but she could see the blotchiness of his skin crawling from pink to red. It made the green of his eyes pop and his brow was weighted at the thought of his daughter being prey to ignorance, she said. And in one of those parenting moments that no guidebook could ever prep you for, my dad said words that will stay with me forever: 'Draw your own box.'    He wanted me to see beyond that census placed in front of me. He wanted me to find my own truth. Meghan has made no secret of struggling with her identity growing up, even saying her 20s were brutal.  She recalls being at home in LA on a college break when her mother, Doria Ragland , was called the ‘N’ word.  She said: We were leaving a concert and she wasn’t pulling out of a parking space quickly enough for another driver. My skin rushed with heat as I looked to my mom. Her eyes welling with hateful tears, I could only breathe out a whisper of words, so hushed they were barely audible: ‘It’s OK, Mommy.’ I was trying to temper the rage-filled air permeating our small silver Volvo. We drove home in deafening silence, her chocolate knuckles pale from gripping the wheel so tightly.  Meanwhile, so conscious his young daughter was wrestling with who she was as a person, Mr Markle one Christmas took apart two Barbie boxed sets, which came as a white Barbie family or a black one, to make a custom one for Meghan. When I was about seven, I had been fawning over a boxed set of Barbie dolls, she said. It was called The Heart Family and included a mom doll, a dad doll, and two children. This perfect nuclear family was only sold in sets of white dolls or black dolls. I don’t remember coveting one over the other, I just wanted one. On Christmas morning, swathed in glitter-flecked wrapping paper, there I found my Heart Family: a black mom doll, a white dad doll, and a child in each color. My dad had taken the sets apart and customized my family. Meghan Markle's rise to royalty in pictures - from starry-eyed child to Duchess of Sussex

title: meghan markles dad sets record
story: NewsMeghan Markle's dad sets the record straight about 'outright lies' - and why he 'isn't in' first wedding photosThe retired Hollywood lighting director, 74, is angered by rumours including that he is "bitter" that his daughter did not pay back thousands of dollars on her private educationShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth08:50, 19 AUG 2018Updated12:20, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThomas Markle has hit out at a number of outright lies against him, including claims that he is a prescription pill addict and missed Meghan's first wedding before she wed Prince Harry . The retired Hollywood lighting director is also incensed by rumours that he is bitter that his daughter did not pay back thousands of dollars on her private education. Speaking from his home in Rosarito Beach, Mexico, the 74-year-old told the Mail On Sunday: I’ve given just three interviews but there are thousands of stories circulating out there and it’s not right that people should be allowed to make up lies and get away with it. I’ve read stories saying I’m a drug addict or alcoholic. I don’t understand where these stories come from. I’ve taken pills when I’ve been in pain but I’ve never abused drugs.  You couldn’t move in Hollywood in the 1980s [when he worked there] without seeing bowls of cocaine everywhere. But I don’t do drugs and I barely drink. As well as the rumours about addiction, Markle also denied stories that he did not attend Meghan’s 2011 wedding to Hollywood director Trevor Engelson, who she divorced just two years later. While photos from the ceremony in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, show the couple exchanging vows on the beach and Meghan’s mother, Doria Ragland, swimming in the sea, Mr Markle is not visible in any of the pictures. However he reasons that the lack of photos of him at the wedding was because he was well into his 60s and not much into frolicking.  He added that he was present at the ceremony and walked Meghan down the beach with Doria, with 100 other guests also attending. Markle said that while he does have photos of him and his daughter at her first wedding, he chooses not to share them as he feels that it would be in poor taste and would be offensive to Prince Harry. The entire resort had been booked out, and Markle said he contributed to the costs by selling Facebook shares at a low price in order to help out financially. He said: I don’t regret it in the slightest because I was happy to help out, but that stock would be worth a fortune now. I’m not broke, I’m not bitter and I never expected Meghan to pay me back for anything. I was happy as a father to give her a great education. I was happy to provide the best start in life to all my children. Of course I never expected her to pay me back for her schooling.  Meghan has not spoken to her father since Prince Harry phoned him in hospital following his heart attack days before the Royal Wedding on May 19. It has been reported that Harry scolded him during the phone call for working with the paparazzi over staged pictures including one where he was being measured for a wedding suit. During the call, Harry scolded him for co-operating with paparazzi over staged pictures, including one of him apparently being measured for a wedding suit. Mr Markle does still hope for a reconciliation with his daughter and if this were to happen, it could come in February. There are suggestions that ‘early talks’ have begun about Harry and Meghan possibly attending a charity polo match in Los Angeles or Santa Barbara, California as part of a US tour. title: meghan markles uncle reveals deep
story: NewsMeghan Markle's uncle reveals deep hurt over royal wedding “snub” - and says he could have walked her down the aisleEXCLUSIVE: Florida resident Michael Markle was "surprised" he didn't make wedding guest list after all he's contributed to niece's lifeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRussell Myers20:30, 18 AUG 2018Updated08:30, 19 AUG 2018NewsMichael Markle has explained why he has been the most loyal relative of Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex (Image: Coleman-Rayner)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghgan Markle’s uncle has spoken of his deep hurt over his royal wedding “snub” and said he would have happily walked her down the aisle. Former US diplomat Michael Markle insisted that despite his worsening health, he would have flown over from his home in Palm Bay, Florida. Meghan’s dad Thomas, 74, had to pull out of the wedding at short notice following a heart attack. Older brother Michael suffers from Parkinson’s disease but told the Sunday Mirror that wouldn’t have stopped him doing the honours as his niece married Prince Harry at Windsor Castle in May. Michael told how he had always supported Meghan and “done more for her” over the years than anyone else.  He admitted that Parkinson’s “is getting me now”. But asked if he had the strength to be by Meghan’s side, he proudly added: “Sure, I could have, if it was co-ordinated. Yes, I would have done it.” Meghan’s mother Doria Ragland was the only member of the bride’s family to attend the wedding. And Michael, 78, said he was surprised he didn’t make the guest list for the ceremony at St George’s Chapel. Speaking from his modest trailer park home, Michael wondered whether former actress Meghan, 37, may have been instructed not to make any exceptions in terms of which family members should get an invitation. He said: “I thought I would. But anyhow, I didn’t hear from her. “And I don’t know how much the Royal Family had influence on her or not. They didn’t accept anyone else so they couldn’t make an exception for me.” Michael was speaking after a barrage of insults and interviews directed at the royals by other members of his family.  Meghan’s dad has revealed intimate details of conversations with Prince Harry, 33, and even confessed how he lied to the Duke of Sussex about faking pictures with a British paparazzi. The photographs showed Thomas looking at Meghan and Harry’s engagement pictures on an internet cafe computer – and him apparently being measured for a wedding suit at a tailors. It turned out they were all staged. Now Thomas feels he has been dumped by his daughter. For years he worked long hours as a Hollywood lighting technician to help Meghan through private school and realise her dream of becoming an actress. With Meghan’s half-sister Samantha boasting of an upcoming salacious biography titled In The Shadows Of The Duchess, Michael insists he is the only member of the Markle family who has shown any loyalty.  He revealed how his connections helped secure Meghan a prestigious internship at the American embassy in Buenos Aires, Argentina, when she was 20. Michael said: “I’ve done more for her than the others. I’ve probably done more for her than most. I personally talked to the ambassador in Argentina for her.” Controversy over the wedding arrangements has haunted Harry and Meghan since the date was first set. The former Suits star told her father there was “no room” for him to make a speech – even when he said he wished to pay tribute to the couple at the reception. Other Markle relatives weighed in with their tuppence worth, causing huge embarrassment before and after the big day. And amid the fake pics furore, Thomas pulled out of the ceremony suffering heart problems with just days to go.  The whole, sorry saga has left Meghan even more reliant on mum Doria, 61, who has been her rock throughout. Michael has previously told how he thought his niece’s attitude towards her family was “uncalled for”. He said before the wedding: “I don’t understand why she has been so &shyindifferent towards me. It’s uncalled for. I helped her out and I didn’t ask for anything in return.” Despite the disappointment at missing out on the big day, a neighbour at the trailer park retirement village told how Michael was delighed about the wedding. After moving in to his &pound78,000 home he told everyone about his niece.  The source said: “He’s very proud of Meghan. When he moved in he asked everyone if they knew who she was and that she was marrying Prince Harry.” Meghan is expected to move her mum from the US to London as she embarks on the next stage of her marriage. She is said to want children as soon as possible after she and Harry return from their first major tour in October. The couple will spend a fortnight in Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand. In Sydney they will launch the fourth Invictus Games, the hugely successful sporting event which former soldier Harry founded for injured servicemen and women.  A royal insider said: “The trip is likely to be a welcome distraction for everyone, but especially for the Duke and Duchess of Sussex. “Royal aides have been increasingly under pressure to find a way out of this crisis as the Markle family show no signs of keeping quiet. “So far Meghan and Harry have decided to stay quiet but something will have to give sooner rather than later.” Earlier this month it was revealed how royal advisers have held a series of crisis summits on how to stop Thomas Markle from heaping further distress on his daughter.  At least three meetings have taken place between Meghan and Harry’s senior team and other royal advisers to find a solution. Three options have been laid out to Meghan to try to resolve the public breakdown in relations with her dad. Our source said: “It’s an increasingly desperate situation and now it’s come down to three options being on the table. “Firstly, Meghan could contact her father straight away and appeal to him directly to stop hurting her.

title: mum 35 who expected home
story: NewsMum, 35, who expected to be home in time for tea dies after routine hospital test goes tragically wrongKate Jones, 35, suffered a fatal heart attack as her husband Stewart, 48, sat in the hospital waiting-room expecting to take her homeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth11:48, 19 AUG 2018Updated13:19, 19 AUG 2018NewsKate Jones, 35, and her devastated husband Stewart, now 48 (Image: South Coast News)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe family of a mum-of-four who suffered a fatal heart attack when a routine test went wrong have won a payout but say hospital bosses are yet to apologise. Kate Jones, 35, went into hospital thinking she would be home to give her children their tea. But crucial errors by doctors triggered two cardiac arrests and she died as her husband Stewart sat in the waiting-room expecting to take her home. He only found out something had gone disastrously wrong when a panicked nurse rushed in asking him for the names of their children - in a bid to get his wife to focus and cling on to life. Shortly afterwards a doctor informed him the simple outpatient procedure had gone so disastrously wrong his wife had tragically died. Mr Jones, 48, said: It was the most horrendous thing. I took my wife to hospital for this test which we thought was perfectly safe and I went home a widower.  The hospital still haven't apologised or even held their hands up and admitted liability and that has been especially hard. It has made everything so much worse. Now he has been awarded &pound700,000 in an out-of-court settlement after a five year legal battle that has left him furious and demoralised with the NHS. Like thousands of others Kate, a highly-regarded beautician who worked for Virgin Atlantic, needed an angiogram to check for narrowing of the arteries. Though she was slim and healthy, she took statins to control high cholesterol levels - a condition which ran in her family. But after suffering a slight heart palpitations she was referred for an angiogram at the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Harlow, Essex. She and her husband were told it was a routine test carried out as an out-patient. On the NHS Choices website it is described as a generally safe and painless procedure. Mrs Jones went for the angiography on October 30 2013, thinking she would be in hospital for a couple of hours and home later the same day. The nightmare that followed is indelibly etched on her husband's mind. He said: She went in feeling a bit nervous but safe in the knowledge it was straightforward day-care procedure. Despite her very occasional heart murmur and high cholesterol, Kate was otherwise fit and full of life, always on the go and running around after the kids.  He drove her to the hospital and sat in the waiting room and the procedure began at about 11am. Mr Jones, is a manager at an electrical wholesalers who lives with their children Siena, 10, Lily, eight, Jaxon, six, in Stanstead Abbotts, Herts. He said: After an hour I saw staff come hurrying from the room looking panicked. It looked like they were running for help and then a specialist went into the room. I knew something had gone wrong but didn't know how dreadful it was until a nurse came out and asked me then names of our children. They wanted this to keep Kate focussed on her children and help her cling to life. I was in total shock. What had tragically occurred was a catalogue of blunders that began when the doctor tore an artery causing her to go into cardiac arrest. The torn artery was serious but not in itself fatal. However, despite the tear being seen, there was a delay of 15 crucial minutes before a heart specialist was called, causing the injury to worsen and Mrs Jones' condition to deteriorate. When the consultant arrived he inserted a guide wire to insert a stent which would have increased blood flow through the artery into the heart. But tragically the connector keeping the guide wire in place broke and, instead of leaving the wire in place and replacing the connector, the surgeon instead pulled the guide wire out meaning the stent could not be deployed. As a result Mrs Jones no blood was getting to the heart, she went into a second cardiac arrest and died at 1.30pm. Devastated and in shock, Mr Jones returned home to break the news to their children Siena, Lily, Jaxon, and Jake - her son from a previous relationship. He said: Kate was the love of my life. She was vibrant, caring and talented, with a unique sense of humour. She was so proud of her kids and she made a lasting impression on everyone who met her. I still find it hard to believe she's not here. Mr Jones is now the sole breadwinner and pays a nanny &pound25,000 a year to look after his children while he is at work. The out-of-court settlement will help provide future financial security for them but came after a five year legal battle with the hospital. No amount of compensation can bring her back and we have to live the rest of our lives without her love, support and zest for life. I brought the action because I desperately want lessons to be learnt from Kate's death and do not want any other family to go through what we have to endure since her untimely death.

title: rose west believes forgiven god
story: NewsRose West 'believes she will be forgiven by God' and goes to weekly chapel servicesEXCLUSIVE: The house of horrors killer has been telling fellow prisoners that she will be at peace in an after-life – despite helping her husband Fred kill their daughterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPhil Cardy22:13, 18 AUG 2018Updated08:31, 19 AUG 2018NewsRose West has been boasting to lags (Image: PA Archive/Press Association Images)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email House of horrors killer Rose West has told fellow prisoners she will be forgiven by God.  Britain’s worst female serial &shymurderer – who helped her husband Fred rape their daughter, kill her and bury her under their patio – now goes to weekly chapel services. And the deluded monster, who blames her depraved hubby for &shy“making me do things”, insists she will be at peace in an after-life. The astonishing revelations come from Catherine Jones, 52, who spent time in jail with Rose, 64. And they follow claims this week that more victims of Fred West are buried in Glasgow, where he lived before meeting Rose.  Catherine, 52, who was in HMP Low Newton, Co Durham, with Rose, told the Sunday People : “She really believes she’ll be forgiven when she dies.  “Will she? She put her own daughter under the patio.”  Rose’s religious confession came after she was asked: “What’s it like knowing you’ll be leaving this place in a wooden box?” Catherine said: “She came to me and my mates and said, ‘I’ve found a new life in God.’” Rose, who was convicted of ten murders including her daughter Heather, has embraced religion so firmly she visits the prison chapel every Sunday. But last night a close family member told the Sunday People: “We’re trying to move on and if Rose thinks that asking God to forgive her will in some way make up for what she’s done then that’s not a god that I would understand.  “There is nothing she can do that would put right what happened. “Really I think that it’s disrespectful to the families because they’re &shynever going to get closure.” Fred and Rose killed, dismembered and buried young women and children at 25 Cromwell Street, Gloucester. Fred, 53, hanged himself in jail on New Year’s Day 1995 while awaiting trial for 12 murders between 1967 and 1987. Rose is serving a whole life tariff after being convicted in 1995. Ex-inmate Catherine, freed in June after serving 19 years for killing a man in Liverpool, said: “Rose blamed Fred for &shyeverything. She said he bullied her and made her do things.”  Catherine gave a graphic description of Rose’s &shybehaviour in Low Newton. She said: “Rose was the main woman in there but she did get stick because of who she is. “She was treated &shydifferently. I’d say it was preferential treatment. The more &shynotorious prisoners got that. Rose was clever, manipulative, clued up. That’s how she got favourable treatment. “She’d bake cakes for the girls. She was allowed to shower on her own, she didn’t have to go with everyone else. “We had ‘social’ every day where we would sit round smoking and chatting. Rose walked past and we shouted ‘Rose, give us a minute.’  “It was when she came over that someone said, ‘What’s it like knowing you’ll leave here in a wooden box?’ “That’s when she came out with all this stuff about ‘finding God’ and being ‘forgiven by God’ and ‘Fred made me do it.’ We couldn’t believe it. “She was blaming him but we all knew what she’d done. Rose does go to chapel every Sunday. She may be trying to find something by doing that but I don’t know what – after &shyeverything she’s done.” Catherine said Rose was allowed her own area where she could do sewing. “It was her sewing room and she made a little tapestry for the door &shysaying Threads Room. “But when she was away we messed about with it and changed it to Fred’s Room. “When she came back she just shook her head and took it down.  “Another time she was playing music in the cell. She was playing When Will I See You Again by The Three Degrees. “At the end of each chorus we were all shouting ‘Fred!’.” Catherine added: “She did get stick, but she was the main woman, she ruled the roost. I wasn’t intimidated by her like others. She knew I spoke my mind.” Catherine also spoke about Rose’s lesbian affairs. “She had a few girlfriends in there, different relationships. “She’d make cakes for the girls. She loved the kitchen, she used to eat a lot. She grassed me up once. I was banned from the kitchen but I snuck in to get some food and she grassed on me for it.” Catherine told how Rose tried to get all the TV sets removed when a &shydocumentary about her horrific crimes was due to be screened. “She tried to get all the tellies turned off. It was because there was a &shyprogramme on about her and Fred. “They wouldn’t do it and the next day she wouldn’t come out of her cell. “She didn’t want to talk to anyone because she knew we’d all been watching.” Catherine also told how Rose had “dead eyes”.  She said: “She walked round &shylooking at the floor, not making eye contact. She had dark eyes. Most people have a little sparkle in their eyes, but hers were cold, dead.” Catherine, who was convicted with another person of robbing and killing a man in a B&ampB, added: “I really regret what I was involved in. My family was gutted. “But Rose is totally &shydeluded trying to blame Fred for everything.” This week calls were made to reinvestigate Fred’s life in Glasgow in the 1960s. Fred was working as a Mr Whippy ice-cream man when he ran over and killed a three-year-old boy in 1965. Paul Pender, a screenwriter who has researched Fred’s crimes, claims there is evidence that he deliberately hit the child. The author has been discussing the case with a man who worked in a Glasgow abattoir with Fred’s first wife Rena – &shymurdered by Fred in 1971. Pender believes Fred used his shed at the allotment to have sex with girls after luring them into his ice-cream van. He also believes Fred learned butchery skill to dismember his victims’ bodies after visiting the abattoir where Rena worked. After leaving Scotland Fred returned to Gloucester, where he went on a murdering spree with Rose, whom he married in 1972.  Last night the Ministry of Justice &shydeclined to comment.  Terror at 25 Cromwell St  Rose West murdered at least ten girls with her husband Fred, dismembering their bodies and burying them under their house of horrors at 25 Cromwell Street, Gloucester. Rose met Fred, who was 13 years older, at Cheltenham bus station when she was 15. Rose’s first murder, in June 1971, was Fred’s step-daughter from his first marriage, Charmaine, aged eight. At the time Fred was in prison for theft. A friend revealed when they visited the house Charmaine was standing on a chair with her hands tied behind her back with a belt. Rose was holding a large wooden spoon and about to hit her. She later said Charmaine had been naughty and had to be punished. After killing her, Rose told people she had “gone to live with her mother and bloody good riddance”. Another victim was daughter Heather, 16. The couple would tell their other children if they didn’t behave they would “end up under the patio like Heather”. Their sickening crimes began to unravel in 1992 when Fred was accused of raping his 13-year-old daughter. Shocked cops soon discovered the couple had been abducting girls from bus stops around Gloucester and holding them captive before killing them. Police discovered mutilated bodies buried in the garden and cellar of their home, which has since been demolished. Victims  1967: Ann McFall, Scottish nanny and Fred’s lover, eight months pregnant.    1970: Rena Costello, Fred’s first wife.   1972: Charmaine West, eight.    1973: Linda Gough, 21, seamstress from Gloucester.    1973: Lucy Partington, 21, university student.   1974: Carol Cooper, 15, from Worcester.    1975: Juanita Mott, 19, of Newent, Glos.    1975: Shirley Hubbard, 15, from Worcester.    1977: Therese Siegenthaler, 21, Swiss hitchhiker.    1977: Alison Chambers, 17, from Swansea.    1978: Shirley Robinson, 18, Fred’s pregnant lover.   1987: Heather West, 16, eldest daughter.

story: NewsSuperdry co-founder donates £1m to have second Brexit referendum - and Leavers are lividJulian Dunkerton has donated £1m to campaign for a second vote on Brexit, and believes there's a "genuine chance to turn this around"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer13:00, 19 AUG 2018NewsJulian Dunkerton is one of the co-founders of fashion brand Superdry (Image: Getty Images Europe)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe campaign for a vote on the UK's final Brexit deal has received a record donation - a whopping &pound1m. Julian Dunkerton, co-founder of Superdry, said he's making the enormous donation to the People's Vote campaign because he sees a genuine chance to turn this around.  Writing in the Sunday Times , he said: I'm putting some of my money behind the People’s Vote campaign because I know we have a genuine chance to turn this around.  I've got a good instinct for when a mood is going to change and we’re in one of those moments now. story: NewsTeen becomes first model with Down’s syndrome to win global beauty pageantEXCLUSIVE: Kate Grant, 19, was overwhelmed with shock when she was picked out from 40 other candidates to be crowned Teen Ultimate Beauty Of The WorldShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKim Willis20:36, 18 AUG 2018Updated20:38, 18 AUG 2018NewsKate Grant had been invited to enter as the representative for her native Northern IrelandGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTeenager Kate Grant has &shybecome the first model with Down’s syndrome to win an &shyinternational beauty pageant. Kate, 19, was overwhelmed with shock when she was picked out from 40 other candidates to be crowned Teen Ultimate Beauty Of The World. The pageant is held to celebrate &shydiversity and people who are “beautiful inside and out” – and supports the Make-A-Wish Foundation, a charity which makes dreams come true for poorly children. Kate had dabbled with modelling before the two-day event and &shyentered it only for experience. And she admitted it was a massive surprise when she heard her name read out as the winner. She said: “I was in shock. My family were all in the audience, &shycrying and cheering. “My dream has come true. And that dream is to get a chance to inspire young people who have Down’s &shysyndrome and other special needs to believe in themselves.”  Kate had been invited to enter as the representative for her native Northern Ireland by the pageant’s director, Taylor-Rae Hamilton. Taylor-Rae was one of hundreds of people touched by a message Kate’s mum Deirdre had posted on Facebook asking for support in her attempts to become a successful model. Kate travelled just 25 miles from her home in Cookstown, Co Tyrone, to the contest venue in Portadown, where other candidates had assembled after flying in from all around the world to represent their nations.  The pageant has three categories for kids, teens and over-20s and is open to anyone regardless of weight, height or marital status. The contest began with an interview by a panel of judges. Kate’s mum was not allowed in the room with her, but could hear her making the judges laugh. Deirdre said: “I knew she’d charm them but what made me most proud was how Kate looked after other candidates, &shyencouraging and supporting them.” That evening, candidates of all ages mingled at a “get to you know you” party with a tropical beach theme. Day Two was catwalk day. The first round was casual, so Kate wore jeans and a white T-shirt. The second round was called Time to Shine, which Kate said “meant hair curled, make-up applied and a sparkling, turquoise sequined dress, channelling my inner Little Mermaid”.  For the formal round, Kate wore a black and white cocktail dress with a side split. She said: “I sashayed down the catwalk giving it all my sass. I just wanted to have fun and truly expected someone else’s name to be called as the winner. “Now I’ll be attending photoshoots throughout the year and will be a judge and mentor at next year’s final. “Most importantly I’ll be involved in an appeal where we’ll deliver hundreds of toys to the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. I want to give poorly children a moment of sunshine.” Kate has previously walked the catwalk at Belfast Fashion Week and taken part in campaigns for boutiques in her home town.Today she will be wearing her sash and crown again at the start of the Red Dress Run in aid of the Chest, Heart and Stroke Foundation in Lurgan, Co Armagh.  But the road to success has not been easy. When she was born doctors told her parents Deirdre and John to &shyprepare for the worst and hope for the best. Deirdre said: “After two sons, John and I were thrilled to be expecting a girl. “When Kate was born it was confirmed she had Down’s syndrome within hours. “The doctor painted a bleak future. He said she wouldn’t learn to read, her speech would be limited and she’d never hold full conversations. I thought of him as she made her acceptance speech up on the stage at the pageant, describing her hopes for an inclusive society, one where people like her are treated as equals.” Deirdre and John agreed to raise Kate no differently to their sons Patrick and Michael, then 11 and two. Two years later younger sister Ella joined the family. Deirdre said: “When she announced at 13 she wanted to be a model we didn’t discredit the idea just because she had Down’s syndrome.” Kate discovered a passion for make-up, clothes and fashion and never wavered in her ambition. But she &shystruggled to get any gigs. Her mum emailed agencies with photos but was &shytold there was no work.

title: tragic mystery baby girl found
story: NewsTragic mystery of baby girl found dead in a sack on riverbank is yet to be solved 16 years onAmanda would have celebrated her 16th birthday this year had she been aliveShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGayle McDonaldColleen Smith09:09, 19 AUG 2018Updated09:12, 19 AUG 2018NewsAmanda's death shook the whole community (Image: Plymouth Herrald WS)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mystery case of a newborn baby girl found in a sack weighed down by bricks near a river in South Devon is yet to be unravelled 16 years on. To this day police still don't know whether the 9lb baby died of natural causes or if she was victim of something more sinister.  Investigators said back when the tiny body was found 16 years ago that whoever was responsible for abandoning it must have been a local as the spot along the River Teign could only have been found by someone who knew it was there, reports Plymouth Herald .  Named by police as Amanda, which means worthy of love, the newborn child with a mass of black hair was discovered by local fisherman Barry Kingwell at Arch Brook Creek on the Teign estuary near Coombe Cellars, South Devon, in September 2002.  He was checking his crab pots at around 8am, when he spotted a sack in the reeds. Inside the sack was a dark-haired, baby girl. The baby had been wrapped in a man-made white hessian sack, which had been placed into a similar larger bag. Both bags were weighed down with a house brick. A post-mortem examination revealed that the 9lb baby was born alive and healthy. Nobody knows if she was dead when she was left in the creek or if she was left there to die. Despite numerous police appeals, no parents or relatives were found.  But a DNA sample was taken from Amanda’s tiny body and through careful examination of the site where she was found and material discovered, police have been able to establish a full DNA profile of the mother. To identify the parents, police needed a friend, relative or anyone who has the remotest suspicion to get in touch. Nobody came forward. To this day the case remains a mystery. A year after the shocking discovery, the people of Teignmouth and police who worked on the investigation remained incredibly moved by the sad discovery. As a mark of respect they installed a marble plaque in tribute to the mystery infant, who medical experts say died within days of her birth. Standing beside the plaque inscribed with the words: “A tiny flower lent not given, to bud on earth and bloom in heaven”, Detective Sergeant Ken Lamont, who led the investigation, said he hoped the tribute to the baby might prompt someone to break their silence.  Sadly, it didn't. To this day nobody knows if the baby died by natural causes or was left to die. Speaking 15 years ago DS Lamnont said: “While the case remains in the public domain there is always a chance of the mother or someone with knowledge of the matter to come forward. “But at such a time we thought that a headstone or plaque would be a fitting end to this tragic incident. “It is unusual to have a common grave marked, although Teignbridge District Council felt the tragedy had affected the hearts and minds of the local community and were happy to allow the erection of the memorial.” He added: “We still do not know yet whether this baby died out of natural causes or whether it was something more sinister, but so far all of our leads to find the mother, father or a relative, have turned out negative. Police were convinced that the mother and father lived locally.  They said that the spot on the River Teign where the body was found would be difficult to find unless you knew it was there and said that the bags could only be bought by local people. “Concealed births are very common but this is very rare as where the baby was deposited is not easy to get to and the mother would not have been able to get there on her own,” said DS Lamont. “It is likely that a third party was involved. But we need to find out what happened. “It could be that the mother was very vulnerable and unaware of what was happening in the birth process itself and unknown to her, or it could be that she is a juvenile who did not know which way to turn.

title: voice sunday mirror no time
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Sunday Mirror: No time to waste for total recall of faulty dishwashersIf there were proper channels in place to identify and track faulty dishwashers, Elizabeth Griffin's life might have been sparedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByVoice of the Mirror22:36, 18 AUG 2018Updated23:03, 18 AUG 2018NewsopinionThe senseless death of a disabled grandma could have been avoided with an effective system to recall faulty kitchen appliancesGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMachines can go wrong. That’s a fact of life. But, as experts say, there’s a big difference between them being faulty and them being dangerous. Elizabeth Griffin’s dishwasher was so dangerous it killed her. The 71-year-old grandmother had a model that should have been recalled. It wasn’t. And it caused a fire that ultimately led to Mrs Griffin’s death. Her family solicitor said her relatives had lost a wonderful wife, mother and grandmother. The great tragedy of Mrs Griffin’s sad is that it was avoidable. If there were proper channels in place to identify and track these faulty dishwashers, they could have all been recalled. Since April 2012 almost 16,000 blazes have been caused by faulty kitchen appliances.  Washing machines, tumble dryiers, cookers, dishwashers, fridges are all high-risk. It’s our responsibility to keep an eye on them and use them responsibly. And it’s the responsibility of the firms that manufacture them to respond quickly if there are any faults. But serious faults can cost businesses millions. Before recalling and replacing items they want to explore every possible avenue. That means delays. In the case of Hotpoint, it took them three years to organise a recall of their faulty dishwashers. Three years. That’s far too long. Earlier this year, a committee of powerful MPs said the government were ‘painfully slow’ in bringing in a white goods product recall system. The Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee said ministers were not showing the ‘necessary degree of urgency’ needed to tackle the problem.  Whirlpool is a case in point. They have a massive amount of work to do to recall a faulty batch of tumble driers. The company points to a lack of capacity, environmental concerns and a whole host of other logistical problems. But there is only really one fact that matters. There are a million defective machines in people’s homes. That’s untold lives at risk. If Whirlpool refuses to speed things up the government must step in. And that goes for any other company dragging its feet - or putting cash before people’s lives. Good decision Since the age of seven Nick Clark felt trapped. Trapped inside a body that didn’t feel right. Trapped in a world of confusion. Trapped in a cycle of suicidal thoughts. Today that will change when the 46-year-old father-of-three steps out to referee a football match as Lucy, the first transgender referee. It is a historic moment for the sport. Lucy is naturally fearful of how some in the macho world of football might react. Bigots thinking of hurling abuse should read why Lucy decided to speak out.

title: you cant blame one doctor
story: NewsopinionYou can't blame one doctor for an ailing NHSLast Tuesday the General Medical Council overturned its previous decision and reinstated Dr Hadiza Bawa-Garba to the register so she can return to workShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAnne Diamond19:09, 18 AUG 2018NewsopinionDr Hadiza Bawa-Garba (Image: PA)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe trouble with the case of the overworked junior doctor and the little boy who died from undiagnosed sepsis is that your heart bleeds for everyone involved. Dr Hadiza Bawa-Garba should never have been struck off – but who can blame the parents for wanting to prevent a similar tragedy ever happening to anyone else? As a mum myself, I have the greatest, heart-rending sympathy for the parents of six-year-old Jack Adcock, who died just 12 hours after being admitted to hospital with vomiting and diarrhoea. His life could easily have been saved, had the seriousness of his condition been spotted in time. Quite understandably, Victor and Nicky Adcock feel anger as well as grief. So when Dr Bawa-Garba was convicted of manslaughter and struck off the medical register, they vowed to celebrate with champagne at Jack’s grave.  This week, however, eight years after their little boy’s death, they were dealt an unexpected blow – and one which has left them reeling. Because last Tuesday the General Medical Council overturned its previous decision and reinstated Dr Hadiza Bawa-Garba to the register so she can return to work. Indeed, they now say she should never have been struck off, and that she was “a competent and useful doctor, who can provide considerable useful future service to society.” Like the Adcocks, I was at first stunned. As Jack’s mum said this week: “How can somebody make that many mistakes, be found guilty by a jury and be able to practise again? If you walked into a hospital and saw that doctor, would you be happy for her to treat your child?” Not me, I thought. But dig a bit deeper, and it is so much more complicated than that. Terrible tragedy though it was, was it also a case of an overworked and under-supported doctor being “thrown under the bus” as the huge social media storm has suggested?

title: shanann watts struggled conceive unborn
story: NewsShanann Watts 'struggled to conceive unborn son' and was due to have gender reveal party this weekendBrother Frankie Rzucek paid tribute to his sister, who was 15 weeks pregnant with a baby boy she planned to name NicoShare&nbspByNatalie EvansAmber HicksElaine McCahill05:25, 19 AUG 2018Updated08:35, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTragic Shanann Watts was due to have a gender reveal party this weekend - just days after she and her two daughters were found murdered. The mum-to-be, 34, was expecting a baby boy, who she planned to name Nico, her heartbroken brother has revealed. Frankie Rzucek also told how Shanann struggled to conceive her three children as she suffered from lupus, a disease that makes all pregnancies risky. Christopher Watts is currently in custody accused of murdering his wife and daughters Bella, four, and three-year-old Celeste. The 33-year-old suspect allegedly stuffed his children's bodies into oil and gas tanks to stop them smelling.  Shanann's younger brother Frankie Rzucek paid tribute to his sister on Facebook. He wrote: She is the hardest working person I've ever known. No matter if her lupus was acting up or if she was pregnant, nothing stoped (sic) her from doing what needed to be done. She was very successful and driven. Shanann was 15 weeks pregnant and was due to have a gender reveal party on Saturday, a friend said.  Earlier this week, Watts sobbed on TV as he appealed for the return of the trio before allegedly confessing he had killed them. The bodies were found on the property of Anadarko Petroleum, one of Colorado's largest oil and gas drillers.  Police yesterday claimed Watts hid his daughters in the tanks to conceal the smell, according to Denver7. A body believed to be that of 34-year-old Shanann was found nearby at an oil rig. The site is close to the family home in Frederick, on the northern outskirts of Denver. In a statement to CBS4, her family said: “It is with deep hurt, confusion and anger to confirm our beautiful cousin Shanann Watts, her unborn child, and her two angelic daughters, Bella (4), Celeste (3) were viciously murdered by husband Chris Watts who confessed to the killings. Please keep Shanann’s parents and brother in your prayers.”  Watts appeared shackled in court wearing an orange jumpsuit. Charges will be filed on Monday. He could face three counts of murder and three charges of tampering with evidence. Prosecutors said they believe the family were murdered in the family home and the bodies were later moved. Police are remaining tight lipped about the cause of death and whether the children were still alive when Shanann was killed. It also emerged today how Shanann had express concerns to her friends that her husband was being unfaithful to her.  It came to her mind that possibly he could be cheating, Amanda Thayer told CBS News. Shanann was reported missing on Monday after returning home from a business trip at around 1am. Watts has spent the weekend at home with their children. Chris said he last saw his wife at 5.15am before he left for work.  Speaking on NBC's Today show , Watts said he and Shanann had had an emotional conversation that morning and had stayed up talking but didn't give any further details. He said: I don't feel like this is even real right now. It's like a nightmare I can't wake up from. He said Shanann was planning to go to a friend's house with their daughters and Fox 31 reports that was the last time he heard from her.  Watts said he saw his two girls asleep on the baby monitor as he left the house. He said he text her numerous times but didn't receive any response which he thought was odd. At around midday, he checked their doorbell camera and saw that a friend had stopped by but no one opened the door. Watts said he rushed home but no one was there, even though Shanann's car was in the driveway. He then spoke to police and reported them as missing at 1.40pm. Watts said: When I got home yesterday, it was like a ghost town. I was trying to get home as fast as I can, I was blowing through stop lights, I was blowing through everything just trying to get home as fast as I can because none of this made sense.

title: powerful 82 magnitude earthquake strikes
story: NewsPowerful 8.2 magnitude earthquake strikes in Pacific Ocean off Fiji and TongaThe earthquake struck at a depth of 559.6km on Sunday, according to the United States Geological SurveyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNatalie Evans01:52, 19 AUG 2018Updated10:19, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA major earthquake has struck in the Pacific Ocean near Fiji and Tonga. The powerful magnitude 8.2 tremor struck off Ndoi Island on Sunday. The earthquake struck at a depth of 559.6km, according to the United States Geological Survey.   The quake was 347.7 miles (559.57 km) below the Earth which would have dampened the shaking at the surface. The U.S. Tsunami Warning Center said the quake was too deep to cause a tsunami. The quake was initially reported as a magnitude 8.0 and then upgraded to 8.2, a magnitude that could cause tremendous damage had it not been so deep. The epicenter was located 167 miles (270 km) east of Levuka in Fiji and 275 miles (443 km) west of Neiafu in Tonga. The area is located on the earthquake-prone Ring of Fire.

title: stormy daniels terrified life shes
story: NewsStormy Daniels so terrified for her life 'she's hired bodyguards and bought a gun'EXCLUSIVE: The US porn star also fears pulling out of Celebrity Big Brother this week, hours before the first episode aired, will make her more of a targetShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGeraldine McKelvie20:50, 18 AUG 2018NewsPorn star Stormy Daniels has upped her security as she fears being attacked by Trump fanatics and other opponents (Image: Getty Images North America)Get daily Celebrity Big Brother updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStormy Daniels has called in security over fears for her life after revealing her alleged affair with President Donald Trump. The US porn star also fears pulling out of Celebrity Big Brother this week, hours before the first episode aired, will make her more of a target. A TV source said she has enlisted two bodyguards and even got a gun to protect herself. “She’s terrified,” they said. “She feels like everyone seems to be against her – Trump fanatics, his aides and even her own fans who will miss out on her appearing on the show. “She is the kind of person people get obsessed over and she really didn’t want to let anyone down but she had no choice. It’s not the money she is worried about – it’s her safety.  “Trump fanatics appear at her home, fuelling her fears.” The source claims she now keeps a firearm in her US home following death threats and is chaperoned 24/7 by two armed security guards, as she believes there is a bounty on her head. The source said: “She regrets her affair with Trump because of what it has done to her life. “She also genuinely fears for her safety hence she has upped her security.”

title: brechin city line up loan swoop for dundee striker scott
story: Young Dundee striker Cedwyn Scott has been lined up by Brechin City for a possible loan move – though the League One side have Championship competition.It’s not known which second tier side are interested but Brechin have reportedly made an inquiry about the player who set Dundee Colts off on their way to a penalty shootout victory by netting the first spot-kick at Dens on Tuesday night.Scott banged in the goals for the Dark Blues development squad last season as they just missed out on the league title to Hibs.However, the 19-year-old has only made three appearances for the first team and has yet to feature this time round and a stint at the League One side could do the hotshot the world of good.Scott could follow in the footsteps of Craig Wighton who had a brief spell on loan at Glebe Park.Despite being a fresh-faced 17-year-old, he managed two goals in four appearances.Coach Jimmy Boyle was delighted to see his side “stick to their guns” in the Irn-Bru Cup victory over Hibs.Tom Bradbury’s back-post header from Jack Lambert’s cross gave the young Dees the lead before Fraser Murray replied in the first half.The visitors then took the lead as Sean Mackie smashed past goalkeeper Sam Jackson after he’d made a string of saves.Dan Jefferies, though made it a centre-half double for his side, heading in with five minutes left to set up penalties.Jackson made two saves to give Bradbury the chance to send his side through to the second round, which he did emphatically.Coach Jimmy said: “When you look at our team, we’re a lot younger than them. We knew it would be a good game, we know what Hibs are about, they are a very good team.“I enjoyed the way we played, some of the stuff in the first half was excellent but we know they have quality and put us under pressure. I’m pleased we stuck to our guns and we got what we deserved.”There was plenty to be happy about including an impressive display from winger Cammy Dow.Jimmy said: “Sam Jackson did great, he’s a confident big boy and I thought Cammy Dow was excellent – he’s a massive Dundee fan as well, which is great.”The second-round draw is today at 1pm.&nbsp

title: dundee boss neil hails the impact of midfield main man lewis spence
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann has hailed the impact of Lewis Spence, saying he’s embraced the responsibility of being the “main man” in his midfield.The 22-year-old former Dunfermline man was the Dens gaffer’s first signing last summer, snapped up under the noses of then-Championship side Brechin City.And despite missing large chunks of last season with injury, Neil is delighted to see Spence make the step up to the top flight so well.“Spence has been terrific since he’s come in,” he said.“I think he’s really enjoyed the responsibility of being in there and because we’re playing with a bit of control in front of the back four, it’s his natural game.“He’s been great.“I always knew what Spence was capable of – it was about getting him to believe it.“He’s a winner but he’s jumped levels to come into the Premiership last summer and I thought he had some exceptional performances.“This year he has come back pre-season and has been given an opportunity in there to be the main man in front of the back four because Glen Kamara generally stole a lot of the limelight in that position last year.“Spence has gone in there and done really well.“We’ve been strong in the middle of the park, other areas we clearly need to add to.”There was a worry Spence would be ruled out for today’s League Cup last-16 clash with Ayr United after picking up a knock on his ankle last week.However, he has declared himself fit for action (see left) and is expected to retain his place today against the Honest Men.

title: dundee colts and united drawn at home in irn bru cup
story: Dundee Colts and Dundee United have been awarded home ties in the Irn Bru Cup.The second round draw has seen the Dark Blues youngsters host Motherwell Colts.Meanwhile United will welcome Alloa Athletic to Tannadice. It&#8217s the fourth cup competition in a row the Tangerines have been drawn against Jim Goodwin&#8217s men.Dundee United dramatically came from two goals down to beat St Johnstone 3-2, with a Paul McMullan goal in the dying minutes securing their place in the competition.The previous night, the Dundee Colts needed to beat Hibs Colts on penalties after it finished 2-2 after 90 minutes.The Dark Blues &#8211 who sported their away top &#8211 won 4-3 in the shootout.The games will take place on the weekend of September 8 or 9.

title: dundee defender jefferies over the moon to grab his first senior goal in hibernian clash
story: Centre-back Dan Jefferies was “over the moon” to have grabbed his first senior goal as Dundee Colts edged out Hibs Colts on penalties in the Irn-Bru Cup on Tuesday night.The Welsh defender leapt highest late on to nod in the equaliser to make it 2-2 and force spot-kicks which the young Dark Blues won 4-3 to book their place in the second round.Being a senior competition, the goal counts in the record books and Jefferies is hoping it won’t be the last.He said: “I’m obviously over the moon about the goal!“I’m speechless – I don’t know what to say after scoring a goal because I don’t do it very often but I’m just happy to help the boys.“We’re absolutely delighted to get through.“We’re disappointed we didn’t finish it in the 90 minutes but the boys dug in and then stepped up for the pens.”Coach Jimmy Boyle was delighted to see his side “stick to their guns” in the victory over Hibs.Tom Bradbury’s back-post header from Jack Lambert’s cross gave the young Dees the lead before Fraser Murray replied in the first half.The visitors then took the lead as Sean Mackie smashed past goalkeeper Sam Jackson after he’d made a string of saves.Jefferies made it a centre-half double for his side, heading in with five minutes left to set up penalties.Jackson made two saves to give Bradbury the chance to send his side through to the second round, which he did emphatically.Coach Jimmy said: “When you look at our team, we’re a lot younger than them. We knew it would be a good game, we know what Hibs are about, they are a very good team.“I enjoyed the way we played, some of the stuff in the first half was excellent but we know they have quality and put us under pressure. I’m pleased we stuck to our guns and we got what we deserved.”There was plenty to be happy about including an impressive display from winger Cammy Dow.Jimmy said: “Sam Jackson did great, he’s a confident big boy and I thought Cammy Dow was excellent – he’s a massive Dundee fan as well, which is great.”

title: dundee man swore at city charity building
story: Reese Ogierman, 27, of the Lily Walker Centre on Ann Street, had sentence deferred until next month.Ogierman admitted that he behaved in a threatening or abusive manner likely to cause fear or alarm in that he repeatedly shouted and swore at Action for Children on the city’s McDonald Street on July 23.Sentence was deferred until September 9.

title: dundee set to announce signing of finnish striker benjamin kallman
story: Dundee are set to announce the signing of Finnish striker Benjamin Kallman.It’s understood the 20-year-old Inter Turku forward will sign on an initial loan deal.The Finnish international has scored eight goals in 20 league matches for Inter Turku this season and featured in a friendly against Jordan for the national side after being called up for the first time – along with Dundee’s Glen Kamara – at the start of this year.Dens gaffer Neil McCann has identified Kallman as the man to help solve his side’s goal problem and he is known to be a strong, skilful forward.It is expected he will arrive in Dundee later today for a medical and will train with his new team-mates.He scored nine goals in his debut season last year as Inter Turku finished ninth and scored twice for the Finnish U/21 side in a recent win over the Faroe Islands.&nbsp

title: dundee united kid glass working to keep things simple
story: In football the most difficult skill is usually finding the piece of magic in the final third that leads to goals.But, for fast-emerging Dundee United kid Declan Glass, it’s the simple side of the game he’s working hard at to add to his unquestioned abilities.The 18-year-old’s form was one of the big positives of the pre-season and a difficult Betfred Cup campaign for the Tangerines.So much so, in fact, some Arabs feel, despite his tender years, he should already be commanding a regular starting place in Csaba Laszlo’s side.The manager, though, has already expressed his determination not to heap too much pressure on the teenage attacker and risk burning him out.There are aspects of his game Csaba wants Glass to work on and the player himself has taken that on board.And one area where he knows he can improve in is, at times, playing the easy pass that keeps possession.“Sometimes I do need to do things simpler. I complicate my game sometimes but I’m working on just playing it simple and that’s what the gaffer and (assistant manager) Laurie Ellis want me to do.“They stress to me I have to play it simple at times and then do the magic when I can.”Not that it’s an easy process and Glass admits when he’s on the pitch he wants to be involved at the sharp end, doing the things that help win games.“I like to create chances and I really love to get shots in on the goal, it’s what my game is about.“I’m an attacking player and I like to excite but you can’t always do that and sometimes it is about keeping things simple and doing it for the team.”As those words show, this is a young man who does not lack confidence in his own ability but he’s also one who gives an honest assessment of his performances.For instance, while he was delighted to have played his part in a young United line-up that battled back from two goals down to beat St Johnstone’s U/21s in the Betfred Cup on Wednesday night, he was far from completely satisfied with his work.“It was a brilliant result, all the boys worked really hard to come from two behind like we did.“Obviously, the experienced players helped us a lot but I thought the young boys, including myself, dug in and we battled and battled.“St Johnstone were no mugs and I thought they really impressed so it was good to get on top of them by the end.“I know I wasn’t at my best but, like all the boys, I dug in and helped get the result.“I was maybe trying too hard at times for the killer pass or maybe trying to shoot too early.“Sometimes things don’t come off on the park but I still worked hard and helped the team and that’s what you have to make sure you do.”As he keeps grafting towards making the breakthrough in the first team on a regular basis, Glass was delighted by the victory, not least because it means there will be further opportunities to show he is ready.“This cup is a chance to get 90 minutes and, if I’m not playing in the league, I need to get games somewhere.“If it’s in the Irn-Bru Cup it’s better for me and the other boys, because they are very competitive, like league games.“You want to win them, both teams do, and it gives you the chance to show up well.“We want to do well in it and I think we can.“I thought our fitness was a big factor against St Johnstone.“We had a hard pre-season and I think we got the benefits of that against St Johnstone because we finished the game strongly and looked the fitter team.”

title: el bakhtaoui speaks of frustration at not playing in right position at dundee
story: Dundee’s Faissal El Bakhtaoui is convinced he can still make it in the Premiership but is happy to have the chance to prove himself all over again at Dunfermline.The Frenchman left Tayside for the Pars on a season-long loan after becoming increasingly frustrated with his lack of game-time at Dens Park.The 25-year-old scored eight times in 66 appearances for the Dark Blues after joining from Dunfermline in 2016 but failed to scale the heights he did with the Pars first time round.The striker insists his opportunities in the central striking role were all too rare under Neil McCann and this term was unlikely to be any better.Now the former futsal star, who joined Dunfermline as a complete unknown in 2012, is desperate to breathe new life into his career in familiar surroundings.Speaking ahead of last night&#8217s Irn-Bru Cup clash away to Inverness Caley Thistle, he said: “I have come back a better player, with more experience. I learned so much in the Premiership, even though I was a bit frustrated at Dundee.“I think I can play at that level but it just didn’t happen for me. I just didn’t get my game-time.“When I did play at Dundee, I think I did well, but I thank Neil McCann for giving me the chance to come out to Dunfermline on loan.“The system we played at Dundee didn’t help me. We were playing just one up front and I was playing as a second striker and on the left and the right wing.“I was happy to play, I was happy to get a game but I don’t think it was my right position.“All my goals I scored with Dundee came when I was in my right position, in the middle, and I’m happy to get the chance to play there with Dunfermline.”

title: get ready record number of folk to walk dundee streets for kiltwalk on sunday
story: A record number of people are set to hit the streets of Dundee on Sunday for the third Kiltwalk of the year in Scotland.More than 2,300 have signed up for the event – the first time it has broken through the 2,000 mark.Walkers will pass through Tentsmuir Forest in north-east Fife before coming into Dundee across the Tay Road Bridge.More than 325 Scottish good causes are expected to benefit, including Ninewells Hospital and Fairview School in Perth.All funds raised will receive a 40% boost, thanks to support from the Hunter Foundation and money raised at last month’s charity dinner with former US First Lady Michelle Obama.Kiltwalk chief executive Paul Cooney said: “We launched the St Andrews to Dundee Kiltwalk last year and it was a huge success.“With more than 2,300 participants signed up, this year will be even bigger.“The Dundee walk, which begins at the magnificent Old Course in St Andrews and features the Tay Road Bridge, is among the most picturesque of all four Kiltwalks.”The event is using three different routes again.The 25-mile Mighty Stride will set off from next to the 18th fairway at the Old Course at 9am.The Big Stroll will set off from Tayport at 11am and the six-mile Wee Wander starts at noon from the Tay Road Bridge Urban Arts Space.The finishing line for all three trails will be the Blue Seaway playground at Monifieth beach, with a party awaiting all those who make it to the end.Six-year-old Charlie Walker, from Inchture, is one of the youngest participants, taking on the Wee Wander in aid of Fairview, the additional needs school attended by his three-year-old brother Munro.Charlie aims to walk the full six-mile stretch by himself.Sky Sports presenter Jim White (pictured left) will join Hunter Foundation entrepreneur Sir Tom Hunter at all three starting points on Sunday.

title: hundreds of youngsters start school at dundees newest campus
story: Hundreds of youngsters have started school at the city’s newest campus.The £16 million Coldside Campus on Ann Street is home to Our Lady’s Primary, Rosebank Primary and Frances Wright Nursery School.Work on the development, on the site of the former Alexander Street multis, started last year.The campus will accommodate hundreds of pupils as well as providing facilities for the community.The new £17m North East Campus opened its doors to pupils of Longhaugh Primary, St Francis Primary and Quarry View Nursery yesterday.Dundee City Council’s depute convener of children and families service Roisin Smith said: “Pupils and teachers will be keen to get down to work in their new surroundings.“The new campus demonstrates how we are investing for the future of our young people through an ambitious building programme“These are state-of-the-art facilities to meet the challenges that our pupils will face in the years ahead.”Coldside councillor Anne Rendall said the opening of the new campus and the development of housing on Ann Street had “transformed” the whole area.She said: “I visited the site three times at the start of the project and most recently in the last four weeks.“It is fantastic to see how far it has come along.“There are some great open spaces and outdoor areas that will be a great asset to the pupils.“We will also be holding our surgeries at the school now as well.“The school is so close to new housing development, which will make the school a big focus for the whole community.“The arrival of the school and the new houses has transformed the whole area.”Meanwhile, a high school in Broughty Ferry has welcomed back a record-equalling number of pupils.More than 1,250 pupils will be taught at Grove Academy this year.Rector Graham Hutton said 236 pupils from Forthill, Eastern and Barnhill primaries had helped the school to equal the previous record number of students, which was set two years ago.He said: “There are so many great opportunities in further education that pupils are making the decision to stay on.“It’s great to see everyone back after the summer break and the extra first-year students joining us from the primary schools across the ward.”

title: locals told to expect low flying aircraft
story: North-east Fife residents have been warned to expect an increase in low flying when a three-week military exercise gets under way next month.Leuchars Station is hosting the joint air exercise from September 2-21.Air and maritime activity will rise in the vicinity of Leuchars throughout the period, both during the day and at night.Army bosses have asked people to be prepared for additional disruption but said any complaints about low flying should be forwarded to the Ministry of Defence low flying complaints and inquiries unit by emailing SWK-lowflying@mod.gov.uk or phoning 01780 417558.

title: some team is going to take a battering from us soon says dundee midfielder spence
story: Straight-Talking Lewis Spence insists it’s only a matter of time before Dundee’s form in front of goal turns around, saying “some team is going to take a battering” from them soon.The 22-year-old is hoping that’s today as Ayr United come calling in the Betfred Cup last 16 at Dens Park.Although he’s backing his team-mates to start putting away the chances they are creating, he knows just how tough the Honest Men will be to get past.Dundee will have to keep an eye on dangerman striker Lawrence Shankland.He said: “It’s going to come, our luck has to change some time because we are getting the chances.“I think some team is going to take a battering soon, we’ll take three or four off somebody, and hopefully that might be this weekend.“It’ll be a really tough game, though, Ayr are no pushovers, I know a few of their players and they are a decent team.“They play some good stuff and have goalscorers in their team so it’ll be tough.“They won League One so they’ve come up with confidence and have goals in their team, boys that can put it in the net.“They’ll come here with confidence but we’re confident we can get the job done if we apply ourselves the right way professionally.“I’ve always said we want a cup run here to give the fans something back and this is a great draw for us.“It’ll be difficult but we win that and we’re in the quarters and a decent draw can see you to the semis at Hampden.“However, we need to take care of Ayr first – we can’t look past them.”Spence was an injury doubt for this one after he was subbed in last weekend’s 1-0 defeat at home to Aberdeen with an ankle knock. He says, though, coming off was just a precaution after needing surgery on the same ankle last season.He said: “It was nothing too serious. I had a shot and rolled my ankle a bit and I’ve had previous with it, so it was a bit of a worry at the time. However, a good bit of rest and the physio saw it. I’ve trained this week and it’s good. I just need to keep an eye on it.”Now would be an unfortunate time for Spence to be ruled out of action after some impressive displays in the early-season games and particularly due to the level of competition in the position now at Dens Park.“Last year there were a lot of centre-mids but again this year we’re very strong there, one of the strongest areas in the team,” he added.“I think that’s good because it keeps everyone on their toes, you can’t slack because there will be somebody else to take your place.“I believe in my ability and I’ve worked hard over the summer, worked hard in pre-season, too.“Obviously, I’ve been in the position but Glen Kamara is to come back and you’ve got Adil Nabi, Paul McGowan, Elton Ngwatala and Kharl Madianga, so there’s a lot of competition in there. I think throughout the season it will be getting rotated round and, hopefully, I can be in that team.“I think I’ve done OK so far. It’s still early but I want to keep this up through the whole season.“Last year I played well in stages and then got injured so I want to play consistently every week, play as much as I can, and obviously help the team climb the table.”And the way to do that will be to start finding the net, something Spence is adamant that’ll change soon.“I think our luck will turn around.“We have to put some of these chances away, we all know that, but the main thing is we are creating chances.“One day it is going to click, something is just missing at the moment but we all believe in the guys up front to go and do it.”

title: too many people have jumped witnesses recall horror as man stands close to edge of tay road bridge
story: Witnesses have spoken about the horror of seeing the police incident that closed Tay Road Bridge yesterday.The bridge was shut in both directions yesterday amid fears for the safety of a man seen standing close to the edge.Police, the fire service, the coastguard and Broughty Ferry lifeboat were all on the scene, with the bridge closing at around 4am.The man was about a third of the way along the bridge, from the Fife side.Traffic was being diverted via Perth and the A90, with queues beginning to build up around 8.30am.However, some motorists had stopped and parked near the bridge entrance on the Dundee side as the drama unfolded.Ross Mackenzie, an apprentice bricklayer with building firm Panbride Contracts in Carnoustie, was on his way to St Andrews for work around 7.30am when police stopped his van to tell him the bridge was closed.The 25-year-old said he hoped the man could be brought to safety.He said: “We got here and were told we couldn’t get over the bridge. We thought about driving the Perth way to Fife but decided just to see how it goes and hopefully the bridge reopens soon.“We were told it’s someone at the side of the bridge and there’s concern for their safety.“Whoever it is, I hope they can be talked down.“Too many people have jumped from it.”A dog walker, who asked not to be named, said she thought there had been a road traffic collision initially.“The road closes for crashes all the time so that’s your first thought,” she said.“Then I noticed the lifeboat and realised there must be either someone in the water or fears they were going to jump.“It’s just terrible someone would want to do that. Hopefully the police can make him see sense.”The bridge reopened on Friday at around 9.45am.

title: wanted mystery man who followed kids to dundee park played tig and took them to shops
story: Police are investigating after parents reported that a mystery man followed their children to the park and said he wanted to be their teacher.One mum, who declined to be named, said that a man had followed the youngsters to Powrie Park in Fintry.She said: “The man played tig with them, took them to the shops and bought them juice and asked to be their teacher.“The police have been informed but I just want everyone in Fintry to be aware of what happened.”Ron Neave, chairman of Fintry Community Council, said he was very concerned to hear what had happened.“This is a big worry for everyone that lives in the area, particularly parents, if there is someone approaching young children and behaving in this manner,” he said.“I will be speaking to the community council and the police to see what can be done.“We have been trying to organise CCTV cameras to cover the park and area surrounding it.“Hopefully this will happen in the very near future but, following this incident, we will be doing everything possible to move it along.“The incident means that parents won’t be keen to allow their children to go to the park unaccompanied, even the older ones, which is a real shame.”I will ask police to step up their patrols in the park.”A spokesman for Police Scotland said that officers were investigating an incident in Powrie Park, Cheviot Crescent, at around 4.30pm yesterday.He added: “A man entered the park from the direction of Findhorn Street, then approached a group of children and spoke to them.“This caused the children some alarm and they ran off.“They later saw him again on Fintry Drive, although this appears to have been coincidental and there is no indication they were followed.“Officers would like to trace a man described as being in his 30s with short dark hair, wearing a blue top and white shorts and with a mole or similar mark on this right calf.“There is every possibility that the man’s actions have been genuine and he has not intended to alarm the children.“However, we would like to identify him in order to speak to him.”Anyone with information can call 101 or speak to any police officer.Information can also be passed anonymously to
